This section of the NHS Evidence - neurological conditions 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Epilepsy focuses on diagnosis.

The 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Epilepsy examines recent systematic reviews, whose methodology has been reviewed and content appraised, so as to provide a reliable evidence base for clinical management. It does not examine primary research.

111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on Hip Fracture - Commentary and Results - Emergency Department Care

Link to Contents Page

This section has been written by Mr Xavier Griffin and prepared by NHS Evidence - emergency and urgent care.

Note: The scope of this Annual Evidence Update covers fractures affecting the proximal femur.
 

 

Context
 

Fracture of the proximal femur is the single greatest challenge facing the trauma and orthopaedic community. In 1990, a global incidence of 1.31 million was reported and was associated with 740,000 deaths (Johnell and Kanis 2004). Fractures of the proximal femur constitute a heavy socioeconomic burden worldwide. The cost of this clinical problem is estimated at 1.75 million disability adjusted life years lost, 1.4% of the total healthcare burden in established market economies (Johnell and Kanis 2004).

Patients pass through multiple healthcare environments during their treatment for this type of fracture. They also encounter a range of different healthcare professionals. This area of the annual evidence update specifically concerns the care of these patients in the emergency department (ED).


 

Background evidence

 
Guidelines

SIGN National Clinical Guideline 111 (2009)
Management of hip fracture in older people

NICE (in progress (due 2011))
The management of hip fracture in adults

 
Systematic reviews and meta-analyses

Cochrane Reviews

Nerve blocks (subcostal, lateral cutaneous, femoral, triple, psoas) for hip fractures (2002)

Perioperative fluid volume optimization following proximal femoral fracture (2004)

Pre-operative traction for fractures of the proximal femur in adults
(2006)
 

Integrated care pathways

Controversy exists regarding the effectiveness of integrated care pathways (ICPs) in the management of patients with proximal femoral fractures (Parker 2004). Currently, there is no nationally agreed or recommended ICP.


 

Annual evidence update 2009

Level I evidence

Systematic reviews

  • No new systematic reviews or meta-analyses were published.

Randomised controlled trials

  • A pilot randomised clinical trial of 3-in-1 femoral nerve block and intravenous morphine as primary analgesia for patients presenting to the emergency department with fractured hip

Other evidence

The lateral X-ray of the hip in fracture: A necessary procedure?
 

Digital image enhancement improves diagnosis of nondisplaced proximal femur fractures.
 

Difference in time to x ray with similar time to treatment decision leads to differences in waiting times of patients with hip fracture in a crowded emergency department.
 

The role of MRI in the diagnosis of proximal femoral fractures in the elderly.
 

Does a traction-internal rotation radiograph help to better evaluate fractures of the proximal femur?
 

Ultrasound-guided hematoma block in fractured neck of femur.
 

Full-length radiographs of the femur in patients with a femoral neck fracture and co-existent malignancy - are they of benefit?
 

Integrated care pathway for hip fractures - a help or a hindrance?


 

Narrative review of the evidence
 

Investigation of suspected proximal femoral fracture

Several studies have investigated the value of plain radiographs in the diagnosis of proximal femoral fractures. Bidwai et al reported that in a series of 71 patients suspected of proximal femoral fractures a lateral view aided diagnosis in one case (Bidwai, Ahmed et al. 2008). The authors suggested that the lateral view was not helpful and a saving of £8430 could be made in their institution per year. Koval et al reported the accuracy of fracture classification amongst trainees with and without supplementary traction-internal rotation views (Koval, Oh et al. 2008). Fifty-seven (8.1%) of all classifications were revised after adding the supplementary view, of which 42 changes were from an incorrect to a correct classification. In half of these cases this would have led to a change in the choice of implant or operative procedure. However, this result depends heavily on local practice with regard to surgeons’ individual indications for fracture management.

Botser et al reported the use of digital image enhancement to improve the diagnosis of proximal femoral fractures with plain radiographs. The Retinex filter outperformed all other filters with sensitivity, specificity, positive and negative predictive factors of 75.4%, 66.7%, 95% and 24.6% respectively. The authors suggest using the filter in patients with a high clinical suspicion of a fracture but negative plain DICOM images prior to MR imaging (Botser, Herman et al. 2009).  Finally, O’Flaherty et al reported a series of 133 patients who sustained a proximal femoral fracture and had a known malignant illness (O'Flaherty, Thompson et al. 2008). All patients underwent plain imaging of the entire femur to exclude distal metastases. None of the patients had demonstrable distal pathology and no patients had been admitted with distal fractures of the femur at the time of reporting. The authors suggest that routine imaging of the femur in patients with a co-existent history of malignant disease is of limited value.
 

Pain relief

Graham et al reported a randomised pilot study of the clinical effectiveness of a ‘3-in-1’ bupivicaine femoral nerve block compared with a single bolus 0.1mg/kg dose of IV morphine in the ED setting (Graham, Baird et al. 2008). 40 patients were recruited and 33 completed the protocol. Patients in both treatment arms reported significantly reduced visual-analogue pain scores. There was also a significant reduction in pain scores in patients in the nerve block group at 30mins compared with IV morphine. There were no immediate complications. The authors suggest that this preliminary data may provide a rationale to test the effectiveness of femoral nerve blocks in large scale RCTs.

McAuliffe and Harmon report a single case of an ultrasound guided haematoma block in a patient with a subcapital fracture of the femoral neck (Mc Auliffe and Harmon 2009) . The patient reported decreased pain scores until the time of surgery, 12 hours later. This may be a technique that warrants further investigation.
 

Other studies

Smith et al carried out further audit of the effectiveness of ICPs. The authors report the initial impact of a locally introduced ICP on clinical outcomes in patients with proximal femoral fracture (Smith, Harris et al. 2008). Interestingly, these authors were able to ‘close the audit cycle’ and implement changes to the ICP after initial review. This may provoke other institutions to review their tools more critically.
 

 

References

111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on Hip Fracture - Commentary and Results - Pre-hospital Care

Link to Contents Page

This section has been written by Mr Mike Smyth and Dr Joanne Fisher and prepared by NHS Evidence - emergency and urgent care.

Note: The scope of this Annual Evidence Update covers fractures affecting the proximal femur.

 

Background

Fractures of the femoral neck are one of the most common limb injuries encountered in the pre-hospital setting and occur mainly in older patents. Typically patients may present with shortening or external rotation of the leg and pain in the hip. Patients may suffer from hypothermia, dehydration, etc. especially if they have been lying immobile on the floor for some time.

Management is directed toward minimising time to surgical intervention by minimising on scene times, providing sufficient and adequate analgesia, ensuring pressure areas are protected, preventing further soft tissue injury by minimising movement and immobilising (Brown et al 2006). Consideration of hydration status and the need for urinary catheterisation may be appropriate in geographically isolated areas or where transport times may be prolonged (Gillespie et al 2003).

 

Annual evidence update 2009

Search results addressing management of proximal femur fractures in the prehospital environment:

• No meta-analyses identified
• No systematic reviews identified
• No randomised controlled trials identified
• No retrospective analyses identified
• No case studies/reports identified

There is one prospective observational study (Roberts et al 2009) comparing on scene times for doctor/paramedic and paramedic/paramedic HEMS crew configurations. Within this study the use of pre-hospital femoral nerve block (undertaken by doctors) for femoral fracture is reported with mean on scene times documented; no data concerning the clinical effectiveness of the femoral nerve blocks is provided.

 

Narrative review of the evidence

There is a paucity of evidence for the assessment and management of proximal femoral fractures in prehospital care and therefore the evidence is extrapolated from evidence directed to secondary care.

Roberts et al (2009) indicate that femoral nerve block may be implemented in the prehospital environment. Graham et al (2008) report that femoral nerve block may achieve a significantly lower pain score at 30 minutes than compared with intravenous morphine sulphate (p=0.045) in the Emergency Department; however their study may not have achieved statistical significance had the authors undertaken intention to treat analysis. There is weak evidence to suggest that non-physicians can safely and effectively perform femoral nerve blocks in hospital (Obideyi et al 2009, Randall et al 2009 – these two papers appear to be reports of the same research), however neither of the papers report any robust statistical method or significant result.

 

Areas of Uncertainty

  • When managing patients with proximal femoral fracture, can pre-hospital clinicians identify those patients who would benefit from urinary catheterisation?
  • When managing patients with proximal femoral fracture, can pre-hospital clinicians perform urinary catheterisation safely and effectively?
  • When managing patients with proximal femoral fracture, which approach to pre-hospital pain management achieves the most effective analgesia; morphine sulphate, ketamine or femoral nerve block?
  • When managing patients with proximal femoral fracture, can pre-hospital clinicians identify those patients who would benefit from Femoral Nerve Block?
  • When managing patients with proximal femoral fracture, can pre-hospital clinicians perform Femoral Nerve Block safely and effectively?

 

References

Brown S, Cooke M, Fisher J, editors. UK Ambulance Service Clinical Practice Guidelines (2006). London: Joint Royal Colleges Ambulance Liaison Committee, Ambulance Service Association; 2006. Link to full-text

Graham CA, Baird K, McGuffie AC. A pilot randomised clinical trial of 3-in-1 femoral nerve block and intravenous morphine as primary analgesia for patients presenting to the emergency department with fractured hip. Hong Kong Journal of Emergency Medicine 2006;15 (4):205-11. Link to full-text here, Portable Document File / PDF

111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on Hip Fracture - Home Page

Published: 27 July 2009

 

Introduction

This Annual Evidence Update (AEU) on hip fracture has been released by NHS Evidence - emergency and urgent care in conjunction with NHS Evidence - trauma and orthopaedics. The scope of the literature search covers fractures affecting the proximal femur. This AEU will appeal to all health professionals, reflecting the multidisciplinary approach required across both primary and secondary care.  However, there may be clinicians who are involved in the management of polytrauma and high energy injuries that affect the hip joint who will find that our update is offset from their area of interest. 

 

Contents

1. Results of 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Hip Fracture and commentaries

i. Pre-hospital care - commentary and results
ii. Emergency Department care - commentary and results
 
Commentary on sections iii to vi
Guidelines relating to sections iii – vi
iii. Pre-operative preparation - results
iv. Surgical options - results
v. Prevention & Risk Factors - results
vi. Rehabilitation & Ortho-geriatric Care - results

2. Horizon Scanning

3. Ongoing Clinical Trials

4. Treatment Uncertainties

5. Methodologies

i. Methodology for sections i-ii
ii. Methodology for sections iii-vi

 

Acknowledgements

We would like to acknowledge and thank Professor Matthew Cooke, Clinical Lead for NHS Evidence – emergency and urgent care,  Mr Andrew Roberts, the Clinical Lead of NHS Evidence – trauma and orthopaedics for producing the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on hip fracture. Mr Mike Smyth and Dr Joanne Fisher for their commentary and assistance in the preparation of the pre-hospital section. Mr Xavier Griffin for his commentary and assistance in the preparation of the emergency department section. Mr Nimalan Maruthainar for his commentary on the results for sections iii - vi. Finally, thanks go to  Emma Bayliss, Information Specialist, Ann Brocklehurst, Project Co-ordinator for NHS Evidence – trauma and orthopaedics, Rachel Court, Information Specialist and Beth Hall, Information Specialist for NHS Evidence – emergency and urgent care for searching, initial sifting, appraising and displaying the evidence in the specialist collections.

111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on Hip Fracture - Methodology for sections i and ii

Link to contents

 

The 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Hip Fracture sections i - ii were produced by 'NHS Evidence - emergency and urgent care'. The aim was to find as many articles as possible on pre-hospital and emergency department care of proximal femoral fracture published in the last year. The decision to search for all types of article was made by Matthew Cooke, the Clinical Lead for 'NHS Evidence – emergency and urgent care', because he was not aware of any high level evidence on pre-hospital and emergency department care of proximal femoral fracture published in the last year.
 

Databases and search strategies


PubMed (searched 11/06/09)

#1  ((hip OR femur OR femoral) AND fractur*) OR (“hip fractures”[Mesh])
#2  ((fractur*) AND (subcapital OR transcervical OR capsular OR intracapsular OR extracapsular OR basicervical OR intertrochanteric OR subtrochanteric))
#3   #1 OR #2

Limited to 1 year, human, English language.
=1004

 

EMBASE via NHS Databases (searched 11/06/09)


#1  (hip OR femur OR femoral) AND (fractur*)
#2 HIP FRACTURE/ OR FEMUR INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE/ OR FEMUR NECK FRACTURE/ OR FEMUR PERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE/ OR FEMUR SUBTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE/ OR FEMUR TROCHANTERIC FRACTURE/ OR FEMUR FRACTURE/ [EMTREE]
#3  #1 OR #2
#4 ((fractur*) AND (subcapital OR transcervical OR capsular OR intracapsular OR extracapsular OR basicervical OR intertrochanteric OR subtrochanteric OR trochanteric))
#5   #3 OR #4

Limited to 2008 - 2009, human, English language.
 =1999

 

CINAHL via NHS Databases (searched 15/06/09)


#1  (hip OR femur OR femoral) AND (fractur*)
#2 HIP FRACTURE/ [CINAHL thesaurus]
#3  #1 OR #2
#4 ((fractur*) AND (subcapital OR transcervical OR capsular OR intracapsular OR extracapsular OR basicervical OR intertrochanteric OR subtrochanteric OR trochanteric))
#5   #3 OR #4

Limited to 2008 - 2009, English language.
 =1544

 

Other databases

The results of the searches for sections iii-vi (i.e. systematic reviews on Hip Facture) were scanned for systematic reviews relevant to pre-hospital and emergency department care published in the last year. See Methodology for sections iii-vi

=0

 

Identification Criteria
 

The results above were combined in a Procite database and 1132 duplicates were removed (the duplicates search in Procite was configured to compare only title and then the results were scanned for any inconsistencies before duplicates were deleted).
= 3454
 

The 3454 remaining results (titles and abstracts) were scanned by Rachel Court, the information specialist for 'NHS Evidence – emergency and urgent care' and any definitely irrelevant titles were removed.
= 167
 

The 167 remaining results (titles, abstracts (and full-text where necessary)) were finally scanned by the relevant section author(s) and relevant articles were identified, as listed in sections i  and ii.
 

The inclusion of a study in this update does not imply endorsement and the Specialist Collection does not accept responsibility for the content or quality of included studies.

111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Hip Fracture - Commentary and Results - Emergency Department Care

Link to Contents Page


Context
Current projections suggest that, in the UK, hip fracture incidence will rise from the current figure of around 70,000 per year to 91,500 in 2015 and 101,000 in 2020. [1]
Good quality Emergency Department (ED) management should include adequate pain relief and initiation of adequate assessment for immediately remediable conditions leading to the fall followed by prompt admission to orthopaedics. [2] Many of these patients are frail and benefit from early geriatric input for overall management.


Background evidence

Guidelines

SIGN National Clinical Guideline 111 (2009)
Management of hip fracture in older people
NICE (in progress (due 2011))
The management of hip fracture in adults
 
Systematic reviews and meta-analyses

Cochrane Reviews
Nerve blocks (subcostal, lateral cutaneous, femoral, triple, psoas) for hip fractures (2002)
Perioperative fluid volume optimization following proximal femoral fracture (2004)
Pre-operative traction for fractures of the proximal femur in adults
(2006)
 
Integrated care pathways

Controversy exists regarding the effectiveness of integrated care pathways (ICPs) in the management of patients with proximal femoral fractures. [3] Currently, there is no nationally agreed or recommended ICP.


Annual evidence update 2010

Level 1 evidence

Systematic reviews

  • One new systematic review was published this year:
    Khan S.K., Kalra S., Khanna A., Thiruvengada M.M., Parker M.J. Timing of surgery for hip fractures: A systematic review of 52 published studies involving 291,413 patients. Injury 2009; 40(7):692-7. Link to PubMed abstract here.

Randomised controlled trials

  • No new RCTs were published.

Other evidence

  • 18 other new papers were selected for relevance to proximal femoral fractures in the emergency department (see 2010 search results below).

Narrative review of the evidence

The time from presentation to the ED to surgery is the best documented part of the hip fracture pathway. There is a consensus that this should take less than 24 hours for the majority of patients. There is evidence from a systematic review of non-randomised studies [4] that early surgery undertaken within 48 hours reduces the length of stay in the hospital and may also decrease complications and mortality. There were no adverse outcomes associated with early surgery. A case series suggests an increase in minor complications when surgery is undertaken beyond 24 hours and supports a 48 hour timeframe for these patients. [5] The National Clinical Audit of Falls and Bone Health in Older People (as discussed by Youde et al) revealed significant delays in ED management of these patients with a third of them spending more than four hours in the department. [6-7]


Investigation of suspected proximal femoral fracture

The initial x-rays can be normal in hip fracture in 1-4% of patients. This merits need for MRI or CT scanning of the hip in patients where strong clinical suspicion exists for a fracture. [8-9]
Recent studies have reiterated the poor sensitivity of standard x-rays in evaluation of hip pain in the ED. [10] Algorithms may be useful based on local practice and accessibility. [11]


Pain relief

A previous hip fracture audit in EDs in England and Wales showed that a significant minority (18%) of patients in severe pain were receiving analgesia within 20 minutes of arrival. [12]
Studies elsewhere have revealed significant delays in time to analgesia in EDs and the commonest reported barriers were cognitive impairment and language difficulties. [13]
Initial ED management includes good pain relief and the clinical guidance from the Royal College of Physicians (RCP) includes tools for assessment of pain in older people and with dementia. [14]

Given the prevalence of renal dysfunction in this patient group, [15,16] it is preferable to completely avoid all non-steroidal analgesics. Analgesia using a combination of fascia illiaca block, intravenous opiates and paracetamol will the preferred approach. Ultrasound guided femoral nerve blocks are successful in achieving good pain relief and feasible in the emergency department. [17]


References

  2. British Orthopaedic Association. Care for patients with fragility fractures (“blue book”). 2007. Link to full text here. Portable Document File / PDF

  5. Lefaivre KA, Macadam SA, Davidson DJ, Gandhi R, Chan H, Broekhuyse HM. Length of stay, mortality, morbidity and delay to surgery in hip fractures. Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery, British Volume 2009;91(7):922-7. Link to PubMed abstract here.
  6. The Clinical Effectiveness and Evaluation Unit, Royal College of Physicians. National clinical audit of falls and bone health in older people: national report – November 2007. Link to full text here. Portable Document File / PDF 
  7. Youde J., Husk J., Lowe D., Grant R., Potter J., Martin F. The national clinical audit of falls and bone health: the clinical management of hip fracture patients. Injury 2009; 40(11):1226-30. Link to PubMed abstract here.
  8. Pandey R, McNally E, Ali A &  Bulstrode C. The role of MRI in the diagnosis of occult hip fractures. Injury 1998;29(1):61-63. Link to PubMed abstract here.
  9. Lobovsky O, Liebergall M, Mattan Y, Weil Y, Mosheiff R. Early diagnosis of occult hip fractures. Injury 2005;36(6):788-792. Link to PubMed abstract here.
  10. Kirby MW, Spritzer C. Radiographic detection of hip and pelvic fractures in the emergency department. AJR - American Journal Roentgenol 2010;194(4):1054-60. Link to PubMed abstract here.
  11. Cannon J, Silvestri S, Munro M. Imaging choices in occult hip fracture. Journal of  Emergency Medicine 2009;37(2):144-52. Link to PubMed abstract here.

document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Hip Fracture - Commentary and Results - Pre-hospital Care

Link to Contents Page



Background

Fractures of the femoral neck are one of the most common limb injuries encountered in the pre-hospital setting and occur mainly in older patents. Typically patients may present with shortening or external rotation of the leg and pain in the hip. Patients may suffer from hypothermia, dehydration, etc. especially if they have been lying immobile on the floor for some time.
Management is directed toward minimising time to surgical intervention by minimising on scene times, providing sufficient and adequate analgesia, ensuring pressure areas are protected, preventing further soft tissue injury by minimising movement and immobilising. [1]  Consideration of hydration status and the need for urinary catheterisation may be appropriate in geographically isolated areas or where transport times may be prolonged. [2]


Annual evidence update 2010

Search results addressing management of proximal femur fractures in the pre-hospital environment:

  • No meta-analyses identified
  • No systematic reviews identified
  • No randomised controlled trials identified
  • No retrospective analyses identified


Narrative review of the evidence in the pre-hospital environment

In a prospective case series of 256 patients Vertelis et al [3] identified that time from fracture to hospital admission is a predictor of mortality. They identified that patients who were admitted within six hours of injury were at a lower risk of death in the first year following injury than those who arrived more than six hours after injury (RR 0.4, CI 0.2-0.8; p<0.01). Ambulance crews must therefore ensure that they minimise scene times so as not to delay time to hospital arrival.

A single case report [4] highlighted the legal implications of treating patients under the Mental Capacity Act 2005 in emergency situations. The case concerned an immobile elderly gentleman with a suspected fractured neck of femur who was refusing treatment or transport to hospital. The patient’s doctor determined that the patient lacked capacity, however the attending ambulance crew (and subsequently the police) had concerns regarding deprivation of the patient's liberty. The case report outlines the legal protection afforded health care practitioners under common law, the Mental Capacity Act (2005) and the Mental Capacity Act 2005 Code of Practice Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards Addendum. The authors identify that transfer of the patient under the Mental Capacity Act 2005 would be lawful and that the ambulance crew would not be acting unlawfully by transporting the patient against his wishes.


Narrative review of related evidence

There is a paucity of evidence for the assessment and management of proximal femoral fractures in prehospital care and therefore the following evidence is extrapolated from evidence directed to secondary care.

Layzell [5] reports on a series of 224 patients who received femoral nerve block administered by non-physicians, however the evidence provided is very weak with no attempt to define patient selection, training provided, success rates nor effectiveness. A conference proceeding by Grigg and Randall [6] identifies that fascia iliaca compartment block may be safer to implement than traditional femoral nerve block by non-specialist pain nurses such as emergency department nurses however no data is provided to support this assertion.

Iamaroon et al [7] undertook a small randomised controlled trial of 64 patients undergoing surgery for femoral fracture comparing the analgesic effectiveness of intravenous fentanyl with femoral nerve block in order to position the patient for surgery. Their study identified that there were no statistically significant differences in pain scores between the two treatment modalities at 15 minutes (p=0.37) or during positioning (p=0.80), concluding that the two treatments are equally effective.


Areas of Uncertainty

  • When managing patients with proximal femoral fracture, can pre-hospital clinicians identify those patients who would benefit from urinary catheterisation?
  • When managing patients with proximal femoral fracture, can pre-hospital clinicians perform urinary catheterisation safely and effectively?
  • When managing patients with proximal femoral fracture, which approach to pre-hospital pain management achieves the most effective analgesia; morphine sulphate, fentanyl, ketamine or femoral nerve block?
  • When managing patients with proximal femoral fracture, can pre-hospital clinicians identify those patients who would benefit from femoral nerve block?
  • When managing patients with proximal femoral fracture, can pre-hospital clinicians perform femoral nerve block safely and effectively?

References

  1. Brown S, Cooke M, Fisher J, editors. UK Ambulance Service Clinical Practice Guidelines (2006). London: Joint Royal Colleges Ambulance Liaison Committee, Ambulance Service Association; 2006. Link to full-text here.
  2. Gillespie W, Campbell J, Gardener M, Gillespie L, Jackson J, Robertson C, et al. on behalf of the New Zealand Guidelines Group. Acute management and immediate rehabilitation after hip fracture in people aged 65 and over. Wellington: New Zealand Guidelines Group; 2003. Link to full-text here.
  3. Vertelis A, Robertsson O, Tarasevicius S, Wingstrand H. Delayed hospitalization increases mortality in displaced femoral neck fracture patients. Acta Orthopaedica. 2009;80(6):683-6. Link to full-text here. Portable Document File / PDF 
  4. Stephenson C, Baskind R, Harris C. Transfer to hospital under the Mental Capacity Act 2005. Psychiatric Bulletin. 2009;33(12):465-467. Link to abstract here.
  5. Layzell M. A nurse-led service for pre-operative pain management in hip fracture: this article outlines a nurse-led service to improve pre-operative pain management in patients with hip fracture. Nursing Times. 2009;105(3):16-19 Link to full text here. Portable Document File / PDF 
  6. Grigg L, Randall A. Pain management in the pre-operative period for patients with a fractured neck of femur. [conference paper abstract]. Journal of Orthopaedic Nursing. 2009;13(4):215-216. Link to abstract here.
  7. Iamaroon A, Raksakietisak M, Halilamien P, Hongsawad J, Kwankamol, Boonsararuxsapong. Femoral nerve block versus fentanyl: analgesia for positioning patients with fractured femur. Local and Regional Anesthesia. 2010;3(1):21-26. Link to abstract here.

111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Hip Fracture - Home Page

Published: 26 July 2010

Introduction

This Annual Evidence Update (AEU) on hip fracture has been released by NHS Evidence - emergency and urgent care in conjunction with NHS Evidence - trauma and orthopaedics. As in our previous 2009 AEU, the scope of the literature search covers fractures affecting the proximal femur. This AEU will appeal to all health professionals, reflecting the multidisciplinary approach required across both primary and secondary care.  However, there may be clinicians who are involved in the management of polytrauma and high energy injuries that affect the hip joint who will find that our update is offset from their area of interest. 


Contents

1. Results of 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Hip Fracture and commentaries

i. Pre-hospital care - commentary and results
ii. Emergency Department care - commentary and results
 
iii. Trauma and Orthopaedics - results
iv. Bisphosphonates - commentary and results
v. Surgery and rehabilitation - commentary and results

2. Horizon Scanning

3. Ongoing Clinical Trials

4. Methodologies

i. Methodology for sections i-ii
ii. Methodology for sections iii-v

 

Acknowledgements

We would like to acknowledge and thank the following: Mr Andrew Roberts, the Clinical Lead of 'NHS Evidence – trauma and orthopaedics' and Professor Matthew Cooke, Clinical Lead for 'NHS Evidence – emergency and urgent care' for producing the 2010 Annual Evidence Update on hip fracture. Mr Mike Smyth and Dr Joanne Fisher for their commentary and assistance in the preparation of the pre-hospital section. Jay Banerjee for his commentary and assistance in the preparation of the emergency department section. Dr Mark Garton, Consultant Rheumatologist at Robert Jones & Agnes Hunt Orthopaedic Hospital, Oswestry for his commentary on 'Bisphosphonates' (section iv) and Mr Andrew Roberts for his commentary on 'Surgery and Rehabilitation (section v). Finally, thanks go to Ann Brocklehurst, Project Leader for 'NHS Evidence – trauma and orthopaedics' and Holly Tricker, Information Assistant for 'NHS Evidence – trauma and orthopaedics', Rachel Court and Anna Brown, Information Specialists for 'NHS Evidence – emergency and urgent care' and Susan Vollmer, Information Assistant for 'NHS Evidence – emergency and urgent care' for searching, initially sifting, appraising and displaying the evidence in the specialist collections.

111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Hip Fracture - Methodology for sections i and ii

Link to contents

The 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Hip Fracture sections i - ii were produced by 'NHS Evidence - emergency and urgent care'. The aim was to find as many articles as possible on pre-hospital and emergency department care of proximal femoral fracture published in the last year. The decision to search for all types of article was made by Professor Matthew Cooke, the Clinical Lead for 'NHS Evidence – emergency and urgent care', because he did not expect us to find a large amount of high level evidence on pre-hospital and emergency department care of proximal femoral fracture published in the last year.
 

Databases and search strategies


PubMed (searched 18/06/10)

#1  ((hip OR femur OR femoral) AND fractur*) OR (“hip fractures”[Mesh])
#2  ((fractur*) AND (subcapital OR transcervical OR capsular OR intracapsular OR extracapsular OR basicervical OR intertrochanteric OR subtrochanteric))
#3   #1 OR #2

Limited to specific date range (11/05/2009 – 18/06/2010 n.b. includes one month overlap with 2009 search), human, English language.
=1184

 

EMBASE via NHS Databases (searched 18/06/10)


#1  (hip OR femur OR femoral) AND (fractur*)
#2 HIP FRACTURE/ OR FEMUR INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE/ OR FEMUR NECK FRACTURE/ OR FEMUR PERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE/ OR FEMUR SUBTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE/ OR FEMUR TROCHANTERIC FRACTURE/ OR FEMUR FRACTURE/ [EMTREE]
#3  #1 OR #2
#4 ((fractur*) AND (subcapital OR transcervical OR capsular OR intracapsular OR extracapsular OR basicervical OR intertrochanteric OR subtrochanteric OR trochanteric))
#5   #3 OR #4

Limited to 2009 - 2010, human, English language.
=2880

 

CINAHL via NHS Databases (searched 20/06/10)


#1  (hip OR femur OR femoral) AND (fractur*)
#2 HIP FRACTURE/ [CINAHL thesaurus]
#3  #1 OR #2
#4 ((fractur*) AND (subcapital OR transcervical OR capsular OR intracapsular OR extracapsular OR basicervical OR intertrochanteric OR subtrochanteric OR trochanteric))
#5   #3 OR #4

Limited to 2009 - 2010, English language.
 =1785

 

Other databases

The results of the searches for sections iii-v (i.e. systematic reviews on Hip Fracture) were scanned for systematic reviews relevant to pre-hospital and emergency department care published in the last year. See Methodology for sections iii-v

 

Identification Criteria
 

The results above were combined in a Procite database and 1772 duplicates between this year’s and last year’s results were removed and then 1550 duplicates between databases were removed (the duplicates search in Procite was configured to compare only title and then the results were scanned for any inconsistencies before duplicates were deleted).
= 3349
 

The 3349 remaining results (titles and abstracts) were scanned by Rachel Court and Anna Brown, the information specialists for 'NHS Evidence – emergency and urgent care' and any definitely irrelevant titles were removed.
= 315
 

The 315 remaining results (titles, abstracts (and full-text where necessary)) were finally scanned by the relevant section author(s) and relevant articles were identified, as listed in sections i  and ii.
 

The inclusion of a study in this update does not imply endorsement and the Specialist Collection does not accept responsibility for the content or quality of included studies.

Conclusion: Non-invasive ventilatory support delivered by either CPAP or NIPPV safely provides earlier improvement and resolution of breathlessness, respiratory distress and metabolic abnormality. However, this does not translate into improved short- or longer-term survival. We recommend that CPAP or NIPPV should be considered as adjunctive therapy in patients with severe acute cardiogenic pulmonary oedema in the presence of severe respiratory distress or when there is a failure to improve with pharmacological therapy.

document.title: A randomised controlled trial of the use of aciclovir and/or prednisolone for the early treatment of Bell's palsy : the BELLS study
document.publisher: NIHR Evaluation, Trials and Studies Coordinating Centre (NETSCC)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,CLINICAL LIBRARY,NEUROLOGICAL,BELLS PALSY]]>
document.body:
Conclusion:

This is the largest randomised controlled trial of the effectiveness of treatment for Bell's palsy. We have confirmed the generally favourable outcome for Bell's palsy, with 63% of patients recovered with no treatment at 3 months, increasing to 85% after 9 months. Treatment within 72 hours of onset with prednisolone increased these rates to 83% and 94% respectively. Aciclovir alone produced no benefit over placebo and there was no benefit from its addition to prednisolone.

This study provided robust evidence to support the early use of oral prednisolone in Bell's palsy as an effective treatment which may be considered cost-effective by NHS commissioners. Most patients recover fully without any treatment. Therefore, for some clinicians and their patients, the option of offering 'no treatment' may remain an appropriate strategy, but they can now have a more fully informed discussion regarding the use of steroids. Treatment with aciclovir, either alone or with steroids, had no effect on outcome.

Method: 2 × 2 factorial randomised double-blind trial.

Results: Please see full report for details of results.

Citation: Sullivan FM, Swan IRC, Donnan PT, Morrison JM, Smith BH, McKinstry B, et al. A randomised controlled trial of the use of aciclovir and/or prednisolone for the early treatment of Bell's palsy: the BELLS study. Health Technology Assessment 2009;13(47):1–154.

Publication history: Published October 2009.

Access: Available to the general public.

111-1About the "Managing Emergency and Urgent Care" section of the collection

The emergency and urgent care management briefings that were previously provided in this section are currently being recommissioned and we expect the first few to be added to this section in early 2010. These new briefings will provide a short overview of key organisational issues in all sectors of emergency and urgent healthcare. The old briefings were examined and deemed out-of-date; these have been removed from the collection.

Key policy documents for emergency and urgent healthcare are listed in the "policy and supporting documents" sections under the Managing Emergency and Urgent Care topic.  These are arranged by year of publication for 2005, 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009 and 2010.  Within each year, the items are listed in date order with the most recent item at the top of the list.  The newest articles to be added to the list are highlighted in red.

There is also a page in this section entitled "Useful websites for policy and supporting documents" which lists useful websites that provide information about management and policy issues in emergency and urgent healthcare.

In the "Health Management Specialist Collection" section you will find relevant 'hot topic' articles, which bring together links on a subject, produced by 'NHS Evidence - health management'. In "Other Specialist Collections" you will find links to other relevant NHS Evidence collections, such as 'NHS Evidence - innovation and improvement'.

document.title: Are PGDs the safest route for your service?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,PRESCRIBING,PATIENT GROUP DIRECTIONS (PGDS)]]>
document.body:
"PGDs take a significant amount of time and resource to develop and implement. Giving careful thought and consideration to whether PGDs are the most appropriate option and the content of these PGDs at the outset can save time and will contribute to safe and timely delivery of patient care. It is important to have knowledge and understanding of the legal frameworks and guidelines supporting the prescribing, supply and administration as well as the use and handling of medicines. This tool aims to guide you and help you understand the various options, giving scenario examples to demonstrate what works well and what doesn’t."

Publication history information: Published September 2008.

]]>

document.title: Assessment and management of acute pain (NGC summary)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,CLINICAL LIBRARY,ANAESTHESIA AND ANALGESIA,ANALGESIA]]>
document.body:
Aims:

  • To improve the assessment and reassessment of all age patients with acute pain by determining the mechanism and intensity of pain.
  • To improve the treatment of patients (all ages) with acute pain, to include appropriate selection of pharmacologic and/or non-pharmacologic interventions.
  • To increase the involvement of patients with acute pain of all ages, or their caregiver, in the management of their pain symptoms.

Intended audience:
Advanced Practice Nurses
Allied Health Personnel
Health Care Providers
Health Plans
Hospitals
Managed Care Organizations
Nurses
Physician Assistants
Physicians


Publication history information:
Original guideline published in March 2008. Revised edition of this National Guideline Clearinghouse summary published in April 2008.

This NGC summary was updated by ECRI Institute on July 20, 2009 following the U.S. Food and Drug Administration advisory on Darvon or Darvocet (Propoxyphene).

Bibliographic Reference:
Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement (ICSI). Assessment and management of acute pain. Bloomington (MN): Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement (ICSI); 2008 Mar. 58 p.

This guideline updates a previous version: Assessment and management of acute pain. Bloomington (MN): Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement (ICSI); 2006 Mar. 68 p.

Access: Summary available to the general public.

This letter from the Department of Health aims to bring together the most up-to-date information on Carbon Monoxide (CO) poisoning and updates the Chief Medical Officer / Chief Nursing Officer letter of November 2008. It describes the signs and symptoms which should be looked for; explains the investigations which may be necessary to establish whether CO poisoning has occured; describes how cases should be managed; sets out the main sources of CO in the home and gives sources of further advice and information.

Access: Available to the general public.

document.publisher: NHS Evidence - emergency and urgent care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,SELECTED SYMPTOMS,CLINICAL LIBRARY,CHEST,CHEST PAIN (ATYPICAL),CHEST PAIN (PLEURITIC),CHEST PAIN (ISCHAEMIC)]]>
document.description: Part of the National Knowledge Week for Foundation Doctors 2007. Reviewed May 2009.
document.body:
111-1Chest pain

Written by Dr Nick Jenkins, July 2007.
Reviewed by Prof Steve Goodacre, May 2009.

PDF version of this topic

Back to Knowledge Week contents

 

Introduction

Chest pain is common.  It is a difficult symptom because the possible causes range from the trivial to the life-threatening.

 

Key Learning Points

  1. Always assess patients with chest pain urgently.

  2. The history contains many clues which can help identify the cause of the pain.

  3. Consider the extremely broad differential diagnosis of patients with chest pain.

  4. Risk factors can help to prioritise and guide investigations.

  5. The cause of chest pain is rarely certain, but:

    • Cardiac pain is often heavy, pressing and tight.

    • Pleuritic pain is likely to be worse with breathing.

    • Musculoskeletal pain should usually be a diagnosis of exclusion.

  6. Do not be falsely reassured if initial cardiac investigations (ECG, enzymes) are normal – further tests are often needed to confirm that the pain is not cardiac in origin.

  7. Never be afraid to ask for help when assessing patients with chest pain.


More Detailed information

Chest pain can be a symptom of conditions as benign as a muscular sprain or shingles, and of conditions as serious as myocardial infarction or pulmonary embolus.  Understandably, it causes anxiety both in patients and healthcare professionals. 

Success in managing patients with chest pain relies on keeping a broad differential diagnosis – if you don’t think about it, you can’t diagnose it!

Patients should be assessed as soon as possible, in case the cause of their pain is a serious one.  Much of the information needed is given in the history:

  • What is the pain like?
  • Where is the pain?
  • Does the pain go anywhere else?
  • Does anything make the pain worse or better?
  • Have they ever had chest pain before?  If so when?  Is this episode of pain similar or different?
  • Do they have risk factors?  (For any of the causes of chest pain)

Examination often adds little to assessment of patients with chest pain.  It is however important to consider whether specific findings are present or not:

  • Focal chest signs (air entry, focal crackles, bronchial breathing, pericardial rub)
  • Signs of acute left ventricular failure (bilat. crackles, JVP)
  • Trauma (flail segment, sucking chest wound)
  • Skin signs (consider herpes & pancreatitis for example)

If the history suggest acute coronary syndrome and the examination does not refute the diagnosis then initial treatment should include:

  • Oxygen (15l/min)
  • Aspirin (300mg po)
  • Clopidogrel (300mg po)
  • Enoxaparin (1mg/kg sc)
  • Nitrates (sublingually or bucchally and then intravenously)
  • Morphine (titrated to effect)

Remember that ST elevation MIs and cardiac-sounding chest pain in the presence of LBBB which is not known to be old may both require emergency revascularisation (thrombolysis, PTCA or CABG).

 

Links to important sources of further information

There are no UK national level guidelines for undifferentiated chest pain; however the following exist for chest pain with specific causes. Differentiating the type of chest pain is difficult and clinicians should always consider all causes and seek help with their diagnosis if necessary.

UK guidelines in 'NHS Evidence - emergency and urgent care':

  • Chest pain of recent onset: assessment and investigation of recent onset chest pain/discomfort of suspected cardiac origin
    NICE
    2010
     
  • Non-traumatic chest pain/ discomfort
    JRCALC (UK ambulance clinical guidelines)
    2006

International guidelines in 'NHS Evidence - emergency and urgent care':

  • Differential diagnosis of chest pain (NGC Summary)
    Finnish Medical Society Duodecim
    2008
     
  • Task force on the management of chest pain
    European Society of Cardiology
    2002

An excellent (if dated) review of best practice is provided by:
Herren KR, Mackway-Jones K. Emergency management of cardiac chest pain: a review. EMJ 2001;18:6-10 [abstract]

2010 annual evidence update on chest pain
'NHS Evidence - cardiovascular diseases'
February 2010

2009 annual evidence update on chest pain
'NHS Evidence - cardiovascular diseases'
February 2009

 

Back to Knowledge Week contents

 

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,CLINICAL LIBRARY,TRAUMA (BODY LOCATION),NECK AND SPINAL,CERVICAL]]>
document.body:
Objectives: To answer the following questions regarding the management of penetrating injuries to Zone II of the neck that penetrate the platysma:
  • Is operative management mandatory or is selective non-operative management appropriate?
  • Is physical examination adequate to rule out injuries to vascular structures or the aerodigestive tract?
  • Can duplex ultrasonography (US) or Computed tomography (CT) angiography rule out an arterial injury in patients with no hard signs of vascular injury on physical examination, thereby making arteriography unnecessary?
  • How should specific vascular injuries be managed?
  • Are both contrast studies (barium or gastrograffin swallow) and esophagoscope needed to safely rule out esophageal injury?
  • Is there a need for immobilization of the cervical spine?

Intended audience:
Advanced Practice Nurses
Nurses
Physician Assistants
Physicians

This National Guidelines Clearinghouse summary published September 12, 2008

document.publisher: NHS Evidence - emergency and urgent care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,CLINICAL LIBRARY,DIAGNOSTICS]]>
document.description: Part of the National Knowledge Week for Foundation Doctors 2007. Reviewed June 2009.
document.body:
111-1Clinical risk assessment and management (CRAM)

Written by Mr Jay Banerjee and Prof Matthew Cooke, July 2007.
Reviewed by My Jay Banerjee, June 2009.

PDF version of this topic

Back to Knowledge Week contents

 

Key Learning Points 

  1. Clinical Risk Assessment and Management: sorting patients into groups with the intention of identifying and managing those with highest probability of suffering from potentially life and limb threatening conditions at the earliest.

  2. Patients presenting to an Emergency Department (ED) could be broadly categorised into three groups based on the seriousness of their presentation: critically unwell, potentially unwell and well.

  3. All clinical symptoms and signs have different roles in ruling in or ruling out conditions.

  4. The physiologic parameters include abnormal vitals and the management emphasis is on correcting immediate problems that pose a threat to life and limb including airway, breathing and circulatory problems.

  5. The ability to elicit clinical signs and obtain a relevant history to aid patient management in the ED depends on experience, technique and time.

  6. Diagnostic workup is dependent on a good knowledge into every aspect of a list of differential diagnosis and it is important to appreciate that a diagnostic workup to detect a disease can take weeks or even months. Any tests ordered must have an identifiable change in management associated with their result.

  7. Immediate identification of risk factors that cause diseases and urgently addressing physiologic abnormalities that save lives is more important as it effectively “buys” more time to aid a full diagnostic workup.

  8. Clinical risk assessment is a tiered approach that utilises different parameters at different stages to assess the risk of potential life and limb threatening conditions in emergency patients.

  9. Concomitant physiologic management is paramount in preventing further harm because of time wasted in the diagnostic process.

  10. The clinical risk based parameters include specific factors for immediate life threatening conditions such as chest pain, headache and abdominal pain.

 

More Detailed information

An Emergency Department poses a particular challenge to an uninitiated, junior doctor which results from a combination of several factors that are a result of complex interactions between patients (such as age, physiology, socio-economic factors, healthcare perceptions and beliefs) and diseases (such as trauma and non-trauma, spectrums of unwell being, undifferentiated and not labelled by specialty). The 4-hr target affecting emergency care also places a time pressure on the efficiency and effectiveness of healthcare interventions in an Emergency Department, requiring a focussed and organised approach to each patient. There is also the issue of differentiating the truly unwell from the worried well in a safe and effective manner. This makes the traditional task of diagnostic management quite difficult and potentially unsafe as although common conditions occur commonly, the lack of lateral thinking which is only effective with total knowledge, makes it possible to miss those uncommon things that in turn could cost lives. Therefore emphasis on a model that advocates a diagnostic approach is not safe and reliable under the circumstances. Triage systems, such as the Manchester Triage system, are designed to determine the prioritisation of patients (how long they can potentially wait) and are not designed to determine outcome such as discharge or transfer to other healthcare providers.

The initial decision with a patient is to determine if they need any immediate or urgent interventions. If these are not required then stratification in to three groups can ensure the patient is delivered to the correct clinician for their needs in a timely manner.

  1. Those obviously needing admission, should have initial investigations and urgent treatment and be referred to the admitting team as early as possible.

  2. Those who obviously do not need in-patient care should have a management decision as early as possible to facilitate early discharge.

  3. Those remaining need a focused assessment of the diagnostic and management needs.

It is well recognised that the earlier a senior member of staff sees the patient the less investigations are utilised and the sooner the patient receives their definitive care and is referred appropriately.

Any patient presenting to an Emergency Department poses a potential hazard that could cause harm to life or limb. Such hazard could cause harm to the patient as a result of the disease process, by failing to identify it or resulting from its management. Clinical risk assessment is a system of identifying the probability that harm would be caused by such a hazard and the management is directed towards minimising this as much as possible by utilising a combination of resources including clinical skills and diagnostic aids. It is not a replacement for the traditional diagnostic system but is better understood as a more basic approach that seeks to identify and address any abnormalities that would at the least safeguard the patient from any further harm.

A “critically unwell” patient has abnormal vitals (pulse, capillary refill, blood pressure, respiration, temperature, mental state or an abnormal EWS).
Physiological scoring systems should be used as one component of the assessment. There are several variations of the scoring systems. High scores should initiate an immediate response including calling for staff with critical care competencies (this may be the ED senior or the critical care outreach team). Medium scores suggest the need for further review by appropriate staff. Low scores do not exclude serious illness as may just indicate no physiological deterioration has yet occurred.

A “potentially unwell” patient has normal vitals but associated risk factors (such as a 50 year old male smoker with chest pain or a 6-week pregnant woman with lower abdominal pain) or abnormal bedside investigations (such as ECG). The risk factors could also include factors such as extremes of age (under three months or over seventy-five years), social issues (lives alone, alcoholic, IVD-user) or even time of attendance to the ED (late night or early morning).

The “well” patient is a rule out diagnosis. Examples of rule out protocols are available.

 

Links to important sources of further information 

Acutely ill patients in hospital
NICE, 2007.

 

Back to Knowledge Week contents

 

]]>

document.description: Part of the National Knowledge Week for Foundation Doctors 2007. Reviewed June 2009.
document.body:
111-1Collapse

Written by Dr Anthony Bleetman, Consultant in Emergency Medicine, Heart of England NHS Foundation Trust, July 2007.

Reviewed by Dr Anthony Bleetman, June 2009.

PDF version of this topic

Back to Knowledge Week contents

 

Learning Points 

  1. Collapse occurs when cerebral perfusion falls.
  2. There are many causes of collapse; some of these are sinister in the elderly.
  3. Key causes include: cardiac, iatrogenic (drugs), metabolic, environmental, toxicological and neurological.
  4. Collapse may indicate a serious underlying pathology.
  5. A searching and comprehensive history is essential.
  6. Careful physical and neurological examinations are required.
  7. Base line investigations include: blood sugar, oxygen saturation, ECG with rhythm strip.
  8. Blood tests should be ordered to search for metabolic causes.
  9. Where necessary, referral for more investigations should be made (cardiac echo, 24 hour cardiac monitoring, exercise tolerance).
  10. Do not diagnose a collapse as ‘vaso-vagal’ or ‘psychogenic’ until a serious physical cause has been confidently excluded.

More Detailed information

The brain requires oxygen and sugar delivery with adequate pressure. Syncope is a common presentation to hospital. It occurs when cerebral perfusion drops to a level at which consciousness and posture become compromised. It may also occur due to inadequate levels of oxygen or sugar.

Collapse may often have a benign cause but may herald serious pathology (particularly in the adult patient). A thorough and comprehensive history is essential from the patient and also from witnesses at the scene. A description of the event is very helpful. You need to understand the nature, duration and type of collapse. Was consciousness impaired? Was there a preceding aura? Is there a pattern to the collapse? (exertion, time of day, after medication). Are there associated symptoms? (palpitations, headache, incontinence, seizures). Has it happened before? Is there a pattern?

Ambulance crews will often have key information from the scene.
This may include such things as type of heating (think carbon monoxide poisoning), medications at the scene, a suicide note, evidence of blood loss (GI bleed).

When considering causes for collapse, you need to understand the patient’s previous medical and drug history. Many drugs can precipitate or cause postural hypotension (GTN, beta blockers).

A search must be made for cardiac disease. A cardiac murmur may indicate an atrial myxoma, ASD, VSD or valvular disease. Ischaemia and other ECG abnormalities need to be searched for (prolonged QT, AF, arrhythmias, fascicular blocks, ischaemic changes).  A through cardiac history should elicit symptoms of ischaemic heart disease, palpitations and shortness of breath on exertion or on lying supine. A neurological examination may reveal subtle signs of elevated intracranial pressure or structural damage. Fundoscopy is an important examination in collapse.

Initial management includes securing an airway and ensuring adequacy of breathing. Intravenous access and a blood sugar check. Monitoring should be applied to any patient in whom there are concerns. The adequacy of circulation should be ascertained and corrected where necessary. Vital signs and observations should be taken and acted upon.

Baseline bloods should be taken when the cause remains unclear. Consider endocrine causes (hypothyroidism, Addison’s disease). On occasion, a toxicological screen may be necessary.

In the elderly, carotid sinus hypersensitivity can cause attacks. This might occur after shaving, fastening a collar or tie and on turning the head.
 
Concerns over epilepsy as a cause warrant referral for EEG and further neurological evaluation.
 
24 hour cardiac monitoring is useful in evaluating patients in whom an arrhythmia is suspected. Anti-arrhythmic drugs should not normally be commenced prior to 24 hour monitoring unless a potentially life-threatening arrhythmia is identified.

It is tempting to diagnose a collapse as ‘vaso-vagal’ when the cause is unclear. This diagnosis should be made only after cardiac disease has been confidently excluded. In these attacks, syncope tends to occur after exposure to unexpected unpleasant sight, sound, smell or pain. Vaso-vagal syncope can also occur after prolonged standing or when in a crowded hot place.

 

Links to important sources of further information

International guidelines

Clinical Policy: Critical Issues in the Evaluation and Management of Adult Patients Presenting to the Emergency Department with Syncope
American College for Emergency Physicians (ACEP), 2007.

Back to Knowledge Week contents

document.title: Defining sepsis, severe sepsis and septic shock
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - emergency and urgent care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,CLINICAL LIBRARY,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,SEPSIS,SURGERY,PERIOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT,COMPLICATIONS,SEPSIS,CRITICAL CARE,CLINICAL TOPICS,SEPSIS & INFLAMMATORY RESPONSE]]>
document.description: Part of the National Knowledge Week for Sepsis Bundles, updated in October 2009.
document.body:
111-1Defining sepsis, severe sepsis and septic shock

Written by Dr Ron Daniels, September 2007.
Updated by Dr Ron Daniels, October 2009.

Back to Knowledge Week contents


 

Patients in hospitals have multiple risk factors for the development of severe sepsis. They are ill, will usually have indwelling devices such as intravenous cannulae breaching defences, and are exposed to a wide range of bacteria some of which may have developed antibiotic resistance. They may be, or have been, treated with antimicrobial drugs themselves, increasing the risk of colonisation with organisms with multiple resistance patterns. They may be elderly or very young, and some will be immunocompromised: either as a result of their acute illness, secondary to drugs administered to them in the course of their treatment, or through congenital or acquired immunodeficiencies.

Severe sepsis is part of a spectrum of disease, ranging from a minor localised infection with no systemic symptoms through to full-blown failure of multiple organ systems- the more common being respiratory, cardiovascular, renal, and hepatic, Healthcare workers need to recognise that each and every patient in hospital is at risk of severe sepsis. An infective cause must be considered whenever a patient presents with acutely altered physiology, deteriorates unexpectedly during treatment for another condition, or simply fails to improve as expected.

The diagnosis of severe sepsis was facilitated by an international consensus conference of the Society of Critical Care Medicine and American College of Chest Physicians on sepsis and organ failure in 1992 1. This defined a small number of acceptable terms in reference to infective processes and systemic effects, which have been refined following a second consensus conference2 and developed to give us a precise set of diagnostic criteria for sepsis, severe sepsis and septic shock.

As teams of nurses and clinicians caring for patients, we are increasingly using physiological ‘track and trigger’ warning systems to detect deterioration and severity of disease. Such systems lend well to the diagnosis of severe sepsis. It is good practice to apply a ‘Screening Tool’ for severe sepsis whenever a patient triggers one of these systems.

 


Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome

The 1992 conference defined the term ‘Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome’ (SIRS) as a systemic response to a variety of initiators, of which infection is one. The diagnostic criteria are similar, requiring the presence of two or more of the following to define SIRS:

Naturally, these abnormalities are only significant if they are new to an individual patient. If, for example, a patient is usually in atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of 100 per minute, then two additional criteria would be required to be present to diagnose SIRS.

It can be seen that no special investigations are required to determine SIRS- the condition can be identified using only routine observations and baseline blood tests. If a patient is recognised as having SIRS, the next step in the identification of sepsis is to determine the presence of an infection as the likely cause. SIRS is not specific to infection. To climb a few flights of stairs, for instance, would give most individuals a heart rate in excess of 90 min-1 and a respiratory rate in excess of 20 min-1. Other, non-infective, pathologies can also give rise to SIRS, including trauma, burns and pancreatitis. This relationship can be summarised using the Venn diagram below:

 

 


Infection and Sepsis

An infection is defined as the presence of microorganisms (bacteria, viruses, fungi, parasites or prions) in normally sterile tissues. Alternatively, an infection can be described in terms of an inflammatory response to a microorganism. A local response is sufficient to identify an infection, but to be termed sepsis the infection must be thought to be causing systemic symptoms- the Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome.

It is of vital importance that those caring for a patient do not wait until an organism is identified or a collection of pus visualised prior to start treating for sepsis. As demonstrated throughout these evidence pages, the early identification and immediate treatment of these patients is crucial to their outcome. For this reason, the criteria to identify infection are intentionally loose- the healthcare professional is encouraged to seek symptoms or signs suggestive of a new infection only. The following list presents the common causes of sepsis in descending order of frequency of occurrence3.


Pneumonia

Respiratory infections comprise around 50-70% of cases of severe sepsis in Europe. Pneumonia is the commonest cause of admission to a general Critical Care Unit. Whilst the British Thoracic Society guidelines for the diagnosis of pneumonia in adults admitted to hospital require a chest radiograph4, it is not appropriate in severe sepsis to wait to view a chest film before initiating life-saving treatment. Therefore, new symptoms including a productive cough or dyspnoea, or new signs such as crepitations on chest auscultation, together with a degree of clinical suspicion and the presence of two or more SIRS criteria, are sufficient to diagnose sepsis secondary to presumed pneumonia.


Abdominal infection

This group accounts for approximately 20-25% of presentations. Pathologies which can give rise to severe sepsis range from relatively common and ‘benign’ conditions such as acute appendicitis, through perforations of organs such as a perforated gastric ulcer, to catastrophic and immediately life-threatening conditions such as ischaemic bowel. In order to satisfy the diagnostic criteria for sepsis in the presence of SIRS, relatively non-specific findings including pain, abdominal distension, diarrhoea or an urgent laparotomy will suffice.


Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)

In most studies, UTIs make up around 7-10% of cases of severe sepsis. Again, precise laboratory diagnosis will often be obtained too late. The presence of new dysuria, offensive-smelling urine, loin pain or haematuria will suffice.


Soft tissue and bone / joint infection

This group includes cellulitis, septic arthritis, fasciitis and wound infections. The classic rubor, dolor, calor, and tumor description (redness, heat, pain and swelling) or the presence of pus on aspiration of a collection or joint will establish a high clinical suspicion of sepsis when combined with the presence of SIRS. Again, this group comprises just under 10% of cases.


Other infections

Important other sources of infection include indwelling vascular catheters, meningitis and bacterial endocarditis. If infection is suspected but the source is not immediately obvious, consideration should be given not only to these less common sources but also to diagnostic imaging techniques including radiology and ultrasound.

If a source of sepsis amenable to surgical or percutaneous drainage is suspected, appropriate investigations including imaging should be immediately arranged to expedite removal of the source of infection as recommended by the Surviving Sepsis Campaign international guidelines5.

 

Severe Sepsis

The presence of dysfunction (failing or imminent failure) of one or more organs, or the presence of tissue hypoperfusion with sepsis defines severe sepsis. The diagnostic guidelines for organ dysfunction and tissue hypoperfusion are summarised below.

 

Criteria for organ dysfunction:

Respiratory: A new or increased O2 requirement to maintain SpO2>90%

Renal:  Creatinine >177 µmol/l or UO <0.5 ml/kg/hr for 2 hrs

Hepatic: Bilirubin >34 µmol/l

Coagulation: Platelets <100, INR>1.5 or aPTT>60s

 

Criteria for tissue hypoperfusion as organ dysfunction:

Blood pressure systolic <90 or mean <65 mmHg

A reduction of >40 mmHg from the patient’s normal systolic blood pressure

Lactate >2 mmol/l.

A single organ dysfunction criterion or a single hypoperfusion criterion is sufficient to define severe sepsis. It is common for more than one organ dysfunction to co-exist- identification of one dysfunction should prompt evaluation of other systems.

 

Septic Shock

Even if hypoperfusion is present at initial evaluation, this does not strictly speaking define septic shock. The term is reserved for patients who remain hypoperfused following initial fluid challenges, which should be delivered immediately in the presence of hypoperfusion according to the criteria above or demonstrated by other clinical signs including mottled skin, delayed capillary refill and oliguria.

If, following the immediate administration of fluid challenges, the patient remains hypotensive according to the above criteria or has a repeat lactate of > 4mmol/l, septic shock is present.

Septic shock is the most extreme end of the spectrum of disease, carrying a mortality rate approaching 50%. These patients require close monitoring and aggressive therapy in a Critical Care environment.

 

Summary

Severe sepsis is recognised as a systemic response to an infection resulting in both physiological disturbance and organ dysfunction. Septic shock is a subset of severe sepsis.

Healthcare Professionals can precisely determine the presence or absence of severe sepsis for an individual patient. As we shall discover, the early identification and immediate management of these patients is essential if we are to improve outcome.

A useful starting point in the identification of severe sepsis is to define the Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS).  This requires the presence of two or more abnormalities in a list including basic observation and blood laboratory parameters.

An infection can be described as the presence of microorganisms in normally sterile tissues, or as an inflammatory response to microorganisms. Microorganisms resulting in severe sepsis are almost exclusively bacteria or fungi.

Sepsis is present when a patient has SIRS secondary to a new infection.

Either organ dysfunction or shock, identified using a list of precise criteria, in the presence of sepsis define severe sepsis. Septic shock is the presence of hypotension or of evidence of tissue hypoperfusion due to sepsis persisting after fluid resuscitation. By definition, patients with septic shock have severe sepsis. As a group, patients with septic shock have a mortality approaching 50%.
A Severe Sepsis Screening Tool summarising this diagnostic pathway is available at http://www.survivesepsis.org/toolkit.php.

 

References

1. Bone RC, Balk RA, Cerra FB, Dellinger RP, Fein AM, Knaus WA, et al. Definitions for sepsis and organ failure and guidelines for the use of innovative therapies in sepsis. The ACCP/SCCM Consensus Conference Committee. American College of Chest Physicians/Society of Critical Care Medicine. Chest 1992; 101(6):1644-55. [abstract]

2. Levy MM, Fink MP, Marshall JC, et al: 2001 SCCM/ ESICM/ ACCP/ ATS/ SIS  International Sepsis Definitions Conference. Critical Care Medicine 2003; 31: 1250–1256. [abstract]

3. Vincent J-L, Sakr Y, Sprung C, et al. Sepsis in European Intensive Care Units: Results of the SOAP Study. Critical Care Medicine 2006;34(2):344-353. [abstract]

4. British Thoracic Society and the Public Health Laboratory Service. Community-acquired pneumonia in adults in UK hospitals in 1982–1983: a survey of aetiology, mortality,prognostic factors and outcome. Q J Med 1987; 62:195–220. [abstract]

5. Dellinger RP, Levy MM, Carlet JM, Bion J, Parker MM, Jaeschke R et al. Surviving Sepsis Campaign: International guidelines for management of severe sepsis and septic shock: 2008. Special Article. Critical Care Medicine 2008; 36(1): 296-327 [abstract]

document.title: Department of Health - Medical Care Research Unit - University of Sheffield
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,ORGANISATIONS,MEDICAL,UNITED KINGDOM]]>
document.body:
The Medical Care Research Unit (MCRU) is a centrally-funded Department of Health research unit.  The aim of the unit is to conduct research that influences health care practice and policy for the benefit of NHS patients and the public. It describes and evaluates services and technologies from a societal point of view, taking into account social and economic implications alongside individual and clinical outcomes.

The unit's core contract is based on a renewable five-year programme grant, funded by the Department's policy research programme. As well as research funded through the core programme, MCRU carries out research funded by project grants from the NHS, research councils, and charities.

The key focus of the research at MCRU is on emergency and urgent care services. It is an important research area because of the need to understand how best to save lives in emergencies and offer speedy efficient care to millions of people each year in need of urgent care. However nationally, there is relatively little research effort or resources put into this research area.

111-1Developing research in emergency care

Compiled by Prof TJ Coats, January 2010.


Developing research in emergency care
Guidance/Tools
Websites
References
Related Management Briefings

Developing research in emergency care

There has historically been little research in Emergency Care, however recent initiatives through the National Institute of Heath Research (NIHR) have increased academic activity in this area. A number of academic centres are leading large RCTs, which will improve the evidence base in this area, however only a very small number of emergency care patients are entered into a clinical trial.

The delivery of emergency care research is assisted by the NIHR Injuries and Emergencies Specialist Group thought the Comprehensive Local Research Networks. These groups work within Regions to facilitate research and overcome barriers to delivery of projects. Within each NHS Region the College of Emergency Medicine has a research lead and there is a research lead within the ambulance service.

The Emergency Care environment presents a challenge to the researcher. The urgency of the clinical need makes it difficult for staff to spend time on trial entry, there are difficulties in gaining informed consent, and patients suitable for a trial arrive at unpredictable times throughout the day or night.

The conflict between the urgency of emergency care and the time needed for research clearly creates a difficulty. Successful research projects need additional resources so that research staff can undertake the trial while clinical staff continue with their work.

There is now a framework for consent in emergency care research provided by the Mental Capacity Act and the Medicines Regulations(1). There is a hierarchy of consent, which preserves the maximum of patient autonomy, but also allows necessary research to take place in incapacitated patients.

document.body:
Aims:

  • To increase the appropriateness of patient visits for viral upper respiratory infection, increase patient/caregiver knowledge of effective home treatment of cold symptom and eliminate the inappropriate use of antibiotics in patients presenting with cold symptoms.
  • To reduce excessive antibiotic treatment through decreased empiric treatment of patients with pharyngitis.
  • To increase the use of recommended first-line medications for patients with pharyngitis.
  • To increase patient/caregiver knowledge about pharyngitis and pharyngitis care.
  • To increase the use of prophylactic medications for patients with seasonal allergic rhinitis.
  • To increase the use of injectable corticosteroid therapy for patients with allergic rhinitis.
  • To increase the use of first-line antibiotics when indicated for patients diagnosed with sinusitis

Intended audience:

document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,CLINICAL LIBRARY,RESPIRATORY,TRAUMA (NATURE OF INJURY),MAJOR / MULTIPLE,AIRWAY]]>
document.body:
'Emergency Airway Management in the Trauma Patient' clinical practice guidelines are aimed at assisting clinicians in informed medical decision-making. They are not intended to replace decision-making. The authors appreciate the heterogeneity of the patient population and the signs and symptoms they may present with and the the need to often modify management in light of a patient's co-morbidities.

The guidelines are intended to provide a general guide to the management of specified injuries. The guidelines are not a definitive statement on the correct procedures, rather they constitute a general guide to be followed subject to the clinicians judgement in each case.

These guidelines are intended for use in adults only.

document.title: Endovascular stents for abdominal aortic aneurysms: a systematic review and economic model
document.publisher: NIHR Evaluation, Trials and Studies Coordinating Centre (NETSCC)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,CLINICAL LIBRARY,CARDIOVASCULAR,ABDOMINAL AORTIC ANEURYSMS (AAA),AORTIC DISEASE]]>
document.body:
Conclusion: Based on the results of this assessment of clinical and cost-effectiveness, and using a set of base-case assumptions, open repair is likely to be considered cost-effective compared with EVAR on average in patients considered fit for open surgery. Cost-effectiveness may vary with fitness. EVAR is likely to be more cost-effective than open repair for patients at higher risk of operative mortality. There is considerable uncertainty in this analysis, in particular concerning the relative cost of procedures and rate of reinterventions. An exploratory study suggested that EVAR may be more cost-effective than medical treatment or watchful waiting for some groups of patients unfit for open repair, depending on age and aneurysm size. Evidence does not currently support EVAR for the treatment of ruptured aneurysms.
 

Method: Two systematic reviews were carried out.  Two new decision models were also developed to inform the review.
 

Results: Please see full report for details of results.
 

Citation: Chambers D, Epstein D, Walker S, Fayter D, Paton F, Wright K, et al. Endovascular stents for abdominal aortic aneurysms: a systematic review and economic model. Health Technology Assessment 2009;13(48).
 

Publication history: Published in October 2009. Updated 17 November 2010 - Next update due: 24 November 2010
 

Access: Available to the general public.
  

This project was commissioned by the HTA programme on behalf of the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence, for development of the following guideline: Endovascular stent–grafts for the treatment of abdominal aortic aneurysms

document.body:
ENLIGHTENme is the College of Emergency Medicine's electronic learning initiative for emergency medicine. This website provides access to a knowledge bank, an image bank, cases, and information on exams and skills.  It also includes links to the BMJ CPD learning resource for consultants and staff doctors in emergency medicine, and to the Doctors.net education materials for Foundation Year doctors and ST1 in emergency medicine.
 

ENLIGHTENme's key aims are to: 

  • deliver the highest quality of knowledge in Emergency Medicine.
  • provide structured curricula based opportunities for self directed eLearning modules for our Members and Fellows in Emergency Medicine.
  • Provide shared materials for others involved in emergency care to also benefit.
  • develop tailored products for emergency care education in developing countries as part of the World Health Organisation’s HINARI initiative. 

Access: Registration with the College of Emergency Medicine is required to access this resource.
