document.title: Evidence-based clinical care guideline for acute gastroenteritis (AGE) in children aged 2 months through 5 years (NGC summary)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,CLINICAL LIBRARY,ABDOMINAL,GASTROENTERITIS,GASTROINTESTINAL]]>
document.body:
Aims: To help practitioners at all levels of experience refine their knowledge and select among the options for evaluation and management of children with acute gastroenteritis based on the most current and best scientific information

In the target population, the objectives of this guideline are to:

  • Improve the use of appropriate clinical and laboratory assessment
  • Increase the use of oral rehydration and early progression to usual diet
  • Improve parental involvement in decision making around the management of acute gastroenteritis (AGE)
  • Improve prevention of transmission of acute gastroenteritis
  • Decrease use of emergency department (ED) services for management of mild cases
  • Reduce the number of hospitalizations
  • Reduce the length of stay

Intended audience:
Advanced Practice Nurses
Dietitians
Nurses
Patients
Physician Assistants
Physicians

Publication history information:
This NGC summary was last updated on 14 July 2006.
Original guideline reference:
Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center. Evidence-based clinical care guideline for acute gastroenteritis (AGE) in children aged 2 months through 5 years. Cincinnati (OH): Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center; 2006 May. 15 p. [50 references]

Access: Summary and original guideline available to the general public.

document.body:
111-1Frail older people in emergency care

Compiled by Jay Banerjee, May 2010.


Frail older people in emergency care
Guidance/Tools
Websites
References
Related Management Briefings

Frail older people in emergency care

In England an increasing demographic shift has resulted in a rapid increase in the number of older people attending emergency departments and accessing acute care services. Over the next 20 years, the number of people aged 85 and over is set to increase by two-thirds, compared with a 10% growth in the overall population (1). This shift will be reflected in increasing proportion of older people in emergency departments where they already account for 17% of attendances. A small proportion of this population is vulnerable because of varying combinations of health and social care problems and can be classified as frail (2) and at increased risk of adverse health outcomes, prolonged hospital stay or readmission (3).
Frail older people present at emergency departments with mostly non-specific complaints including falls, immobility, incontinence and sepsis. Multiple co-morbidities, polypharmacy and inadequate access to information compounded by assessment by relatively inexperienced frontline staff working within time constraints, contribute to their longer stays in emergency departments and are associated with higher admission rates. Increasingly, falls in older people have become one of the largest complaints responded to by ambulance services and admitted to emergency departments.
The validated Identification of Seniors at Risk (ISAR) tool (4) can reduce the rate of functional decline, death and readmission in patients discharged from emergency departments (sensitivity 94% at 6 months) as can multidisciplinary evaluation and access to comprehensive geriatric assessment and management (5), (6).
Acute geriatric inpatient units are effective (7) including specific interventions for hip fractures, delirium and dementia care and functional and nutritional assessment. Effective discharge planning, community management and reablement need close integrated working between health and social care. Excellent communication between primary and secondary care is crucial to the success of these ventures especially if combined with geriatric support across the interface (8).
Conversely, acute care settings associated with invasive management, technological advances, risk averseness and an increased emphasis on biomedical models of care as opposed to the bio-psychosocial model, may not be the most conducive to the care of frail older people.
The need to preserve evidence based high quality care for older people despite increasingly cost prohibitive acute care combined with current financial challenges and associated with the demographic change is one of the biggest challenges facing the NHS now and for the future.

Guidance/Tools

British Geriatrics Society. The older person in the accident and emergency department - good practice guide. March 2008.
Department of Health. Urgent care pathways for older people with complex needs. November 2007.
National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence. The assessment and prevention of falls in older people. November 2004.
Department of Health. NSF for older people. May 2001.
Websites

British Geriatrics Society

References
  1. Wanless D. Securing good care for older people: taking a long term view. London: Kings Fund; 2006.
  2. Ferguson C, Woodard J, Conroy S, Banerjee J. Operationalising frailty definitions in the emergency department: a mapping exercise. The Journal of Nutrition, Health and Aging 2009;13(Supplement 1):S266.
  3. Woodard J, Gladman J, Conroy  S. Frail Older People at the Interface. The Journal of Nutrition, Health and Aging 2009;13(Supplement 1):S308.
  4. McCusker J, Bellavance F, Cardin S, Trépanier S, Verdon J, Ardman O. Detection of older people at increased risk of adverse health outcomes after an emergency visit: the ISAR screening tool. Journal of the American Geriatric Society 1999;47(10). [abstract].
  5. Rubenstein LZ, Stuck AE, Siu AL, Wieland D. Impacts of geriatric evaluation and management programs on defined outcomes: overview of the evidence. Journal of the American Geriatric Society 1991; 39(9 Pt 2):17S-18S. [abstract].
  6. Caplan GA, Williams AJ, Daly B, Abraham K. A randomized, controlled trial of comprehensive geriatric assessment and multidisciplinary intervention after discharge of elderly from the emergency department: the DEED II study. Journal of the American Geriatrics Society 2004;52(9):1417-23. Free full text is available to NHS staff via NHS Evidence.
  7. Baztán JJ, Suárez-Garcia FM, López-Arrieta J, Rodríguez-Mañas L, Rodríguez-Artalejo, F. Effectiveness of acute geriatric units on functional decline, living at home, and case fatality among older patients admitted to hospital for acute medical disorders: meta-analysis. BMJ 2009;338:b50.
  8. Conroy S, Ferguson C, Woodard J, Banerjee J. Interface geriatrics: evidence based care for frail older people with medical crises. British Journal of Hospital Medicine 2010;71(2):98-101. [Abstract].

Management Briefings are short briefing papers produced by experienced emergency care personnel. Their purpose is to provide a brief introduction to topics of current concern with links to more detailed key documents. Readers are advised to consider further information before acting on information contained in these Management Briefings. Additional resources that have come available since publication will be added with the symbol NEW! and announced via out 'What's New email alert and RSS feed.

This briefing will be reviewed and updated: July 2011

This report aims to provide guidance to emergency care practitioners on field triage. Field triage can be defined as the practice of:

Author's objectives

To identify strategies to improve pre-hospital care for clubbers

 

Author's conclusions

Working with key stakeholders in the local community, we have developed guidelines that can be used to improve the pre-hospital care of clubber unwell with recreational drug toxicity, and demonstrated that individuals with a variety of medical knowledge can be trained to use these guidelines. Wider dissemination of these guidelines, both regionally, nationally and potentially internationally, may help to reduce the pre-hospital morbidity and mortality associated with recreational drug toxicity encountered in club environments.

document.body:
111-1Improving ambulance response times

Compiled by Dr John Stephenson, August 2010.


Ambulance response times
Guidance/Tools
Reports and Consultation Documents
References
Related Management Briefings

Ambulance response times

Ambulance response times are a crude but effective measure of the ability to deliver immediate medical care to those calling 999 with a perceived medical need. Response times as a performance standard have gone through several stages of development over the years. They were initially introduced in 1974 as the Orcon standards which differentiated between rural and urban services but not clinical need. These were revised in 1996 to the now universal category A 8 minute target and the category B 19 minute target.  This change was underpinned by an assumption that by targeting the fastest response to the most serious calls more lives would be saved. Initially the clock started once patient details were identified but concerns that this led to inconsistent reporting resulted in the current, standardised process known as Call Connect which is where the clock starts as the call is transferred from the operator to the ambulance switchboard.  999 calls are categorised by the call handler using a triage system to determine the potential seriousness of the problem. A category A call is for an immediately life threatening emergency such as chest pain, breathing difficulties or cardiac arrest. Category B calls include potentially serious calls which do not have immediate concern for breathing and consciousness levels such as road traffic collisions, abdominal pain and fits. The categorisation is however not precise e.g. some cardiac arrests may be categorised as C whereas many non life threatening cases are categorised A. This reflects the difficulty in assessing clinical priority from a telephone call which may also be from a third party. [1]

There is a lack of evidence that the actual target times of 8 minutes and 19 minutes have any impact on outcome for the majority of patients who call 999, [2-3] although there is clear evidence for cardiac arrests that the quicker a defibrillator is deployed the better the outcome. [3-5]

The final category of ambulance calls is category C which has a locally defined target that varies across the country. These calls are for non-life threatening emergencies and would receive a non-blue light, or cold response and include conditions such as simple falls, headaches without worrying features and other minor ailments. Historically the ambulance services would send an ambulance to every call, but now the more minor ailments may receive telephone advice or be advised to contact another service such as their general medical practitioner. The potential benefit of these alternative responses is that they can provide a more clinically appropriate response and free up ambulance resources so that response times to category A calls can be improved. [3]

More recently there has been a review of some of the response time targets for specific clinical groups where there has been no change in the care available from ambulance staff, but  hospital care has advanced to the stage where the timeliness of arrival at hospital can affect the effectiveness of treatment available. Such an example is acute stroke patients, who previously would have received a category B response, but now for new onset symptoms will receive a category A response as these may patients may require early thrombolysis (clot busting) treatment and so even shaving 10 minutes off the time to arrive at hospital is important.

document.body:
111-1Improving flow of emergency patients through the hospital

Compiled by Simon Walford MD FRCP, May 2010


What is the importance of improving flow of emergency patients through the hospital?
Guidance/Tools
Reports and Consultation Documents
References
Related Management Briefings

What is the importance of improving flow of emergency patients through the hospital?

Unscheduled care pathways in hospital are driven only by the flow of patients who arrive at the door. Whilst there may be opportunities for commissioners to modify the way the hospital is used, once they arrive, the patients’ needs have to be met promptly, safely and  efficiently. The hospital must therefore understand the anticipated flow of unscheduled patients into its various specialties and ensure that it plans resources to be available. It must keep a close watch on the actual versus the anticipated demand and on the hour-by-hour flow of patients through the system and be able to escalate resources appropriately if demand rises or bottlenecks appear. Just how prompt, safe and resilient these unscheduled care services will be for patients will be profoundly affected by the clinical efficiency and effectiveness of downstream specialist care, by length of stay, by discharge planning and by the efficiency of partnerships for onward health and community support, particularly for the 20% or so of frailer patients whose needs on leaving hospital will remain complex and for those with long term conditions. 

Modelling demand is practically straight forward because many of the sources of variation can be anticipated.(1) Good clinical practice requires that patients are assessed by consultants within hours of arrival because it improves outcomes and with daily review shortens length of stay. Medical assessment units and short stay wards are increasingly led by specialist acute physicians where upwards of 60% of the patients referred will spend fewer than three nights in hospital.  In general surgery, similar efficiencies are enabled by surgical assessment units, often using specialist nurse practitioner assessment and next day day-case surgery for minor but common problems such as abscess. Length of stay beyond ten nights in an acute bed varies from about 11-18%, reflecting the availability of daily review by senior doctors, pro-active discharge planning by nurse managers and good working arrangements between the hospital and the heath and community care teams supporting frailer people with complex needs and those with long term conditions.

document.description: Part of the National Knowledge Week for Sepsis Bundles, updated in October 2009.
document.body:
111-1Incidence, mortality and economic burden of sepsis

Written by Dr Ron Daniels, September 2007.
Updated by Dr Ron Daniels, October 2009.

Back to Knowledge Week contents


Sepsis, or more specifically severe sepsis (defined as sepsis with organ dysfunction), is a relatively common condition with a major impact on healthcare resources and expenditure. The incidence in the European Union has been estimated at 90.4 cases per 100,000 population, as opposed to 58/100,000 for breast cancer 1. In other words, an individual is around 60% more likely to develop severe sepsis in a lifetime than they are to be diagnosed with breast cancer.

The documented incidence of sepsis worldwide is 1.8 million cases annually, but this figure is produced on the back of low rates of recognition and diagnosis and a tendency to record the causative pathology (e.g, pneumonia) rather than the systemic condition. Recent estimates give an incidence of sepsis requiring intensive care admission of 0.25 to 0.38 in 1000 population, giving rise to around 2 million cases admitted to Intensive Care units alone 2,3 .

In 1992, it was estimated that 1,400 people worldwide were dying each day from severe sepsis 4. The true figure is likely to be much higher and rising. One credible study attempting to identify the incidence of all cases in the U.S estimated 3.0 cases to occur per 1000 population per year5. This would give an estimate of 20 million cases per year. With a mortality of around 35%, this would mean around 20,000 deaths per day worldwide. In the U.K, we might expect to see 64,000 deaths annually from severe sepsis if this estimated incidence were true.

A more direct estimate may be obtained from existing data. In the United Kingdom during the latter 6 months of 2005, over 8,300 patients died from severe sepsis on, or following discharge from, Intensive Care Units (ICUs) submitting data to the Intensive Care National Audit and Research Centre (ICNARC)6. Approximately 65-70% of eligible ICUs in the United Kingdom contributed data to ICNARC at the time, and only around 70% of patients with severe sepsis are treated on an ICU- the remainder being managed in a High Dependency Unit or on the ward7. This gives an estimated 36,800 deaths from severe sepsis annually in the United Kingdom. This is likely to be an underestimate- deaths are frequently attributed to the underlying condition (for example, pneumonia) rather than to the systemic sequelae.

Even using the conservative figure of 36,800 deaths: putting this number into perspective, lung cancer- the biggest killer after cardiovascular disease- claimed just under 35,000 lives in 2003, bowel cancer around 15,000 and breast cancer 10,000 7. Therefore, severe sepsis is likely to claim more lives than lung cancer, and more than breast and bowel cancer combined.

The mortality rate from severe sepsis has been estimated in a number of studies as between 28 and 50% 5,9,10. More recently, the SOAP study in Europe observed an overall hospital mortality of 36% 11. Data from ICNARC shows that patients admitted to Intensive Care Units in the United Kingdom with severe sepsis have a 39.8% risk of death. There are few disease processes with such a high mortality. An admission with severe sepsis places the patient at a level of risk around 6 times greater than if he were admitted with an acute myocardial infarction, and 4-5 times greater than if he had suffered an acute stroke.

Critical Care Units (incorporating Intensive Care and High Dependency Care in most UK hospitals) comprise one of the most expensive areas to care for a patient. A large part of this expense- over 50%- arises from the high nurse-to-patient ratio needed to provide the required level of care. Most Units in the UK estimate that a typical bed day costs around £1500. The cost for patients with severe sepsis is likely to be higher due to their greater dependency. It has been estimated in European studies that a typical episode of severe sepsis costs a healthcare organisation approximately 25,000 euros11. Assuming that we see 100,000 cases of severe sepsis per annum, this equates to a direct cost to the NHS of over £2.3 billion. The annual cost to Europe as a whole has been estimated to be approximately €7.6 billion1.

Since sepsis is not a disease confined to the elderly, far greater costs to the community as a whole are realised in loss of productivity, with the real cost to the economy as a whole of each episode perhaps 4 or 5 times this sum.

In summary, sepsis needs to be accepted as the second biggest killer in the United Kingdom, with a huge impact on health economy and on resources- at any one time, a third of our Critical Care capacity is occupied by patients with severe sepsis. The mortality from the condition remains unacceptably high, and has been compared to the mortality from acute myocardial infarction in the 1960s. We need to embrace interventions which have been shown to improve the outcome for these patients, and strive together as a healthcare community to both reduce the incidence of sepsis, and to implement processes to ensure that the highest standard of care is delivered to all patients at the earliest opportunity.

document.title: Medical response to radiation incidents and radionuclear threats
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,RADIOLOGICAL AND NUCLEAR,CBRN,CONTINGENCY]]>
document.body:
Summary:
Aims (taken from original article): "We aim to advise on the basic medical management of radiation sickness and radiation injuries, and to draw attention to information and training related to early recognition of and medical response to radiation accidents and radionuclear threats."

Contents (taken from original article):
  • Introduction
  • Methods
  • Global statistics and main causes of radiation accidents
  • Typical exposure scenario of recent radiation accidents
  • Radiation sickness
  • Radiation injury of the skin
  • Clinical suspicion
  • Early management of contaminated patients
  • Strategy and safety aspects of the medical response to radiation injuries

Method (taken from original article): "We collected information for this review from our own experience in teaching radiation emergency medicine at national and international training workshops and consulting and treating patients with radiation sickness or radiation injuries, discussions with other experts, reviewing publications of the World Health Organization and International Atomic Energy Agency,8-10 15-17 and from Medline searches using the terms "nuclear terrorism", "radiological terrorism", "radionuclear threat", "radiation accidents", "radiation incidents", "radiation sickness", "radiation injury", "contamination", "medical response", and "medical management"."

Citation: Turai I, Veress K, Günalp B, Souchkevitch G. Medical response to radiation incidents and radionuclear threats. BMJ. 2004 Mar 6;328(7439):568-72.

Access: Full-text available to the general public.

document.title: MHRA Public consultation (MLX 348): Proposal for amendments to medicines legislation to allow supply and administration of medicines by members of the Armed Forces
document.publisher: Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,PRESCRIBING,OTHER PRESCRIBING,GENERAL]]>
document.body:
The MHRA Public consultation MLX 348 sought views on proposals to allow members of the Armed Forces to supply and administer medicines in emergencies or in circumstances where customary levels of medical support may not be available due to the isolation of the location or other circumstances.

Consultation letter MLX 348 was issued on 1 July 2008 with a deadline for comments of 24 September. It was circulated to a range of interested organisations throughout the UK and a copy appeared on the MHRA website. The MHRA received 12 responses, of which three related to the devolved administrations.

The replies can be categorised as follows:

  • Medical/Pharmaceutical organisations - 6
  • Armed Forces interests - 1
  • NHS bodies - 3
  • Individuals - 2

Nine of the replies expressed broad support for the proposals. Three made no comment on the proposals or expressed no preference. None of the responses expressed opposition to the general principle of allowing members of the armed forces to supply and administer medicines.

This section of the MHRA website provides links to the full proposal and a summary of the comments made.
 

Publication history information: The consultation letter was issued on 1 July 2008, the outcome was reported in December 2009.
 

Access: Available to the general public.

 

]]>

document.body:
111-1New roles in emergency care

Compiled by Garry Swann, August 2010


New and developing roles in emergency care
Guidance/Tools
Reports and Consultation Documents
Websites
References
Related Management Briefings

New and developing roles in emergency care

This briefing will provide information and guidance for the health professionals related to new and developing roles and will be updated annually or when key developments occur with regard to the introduction of a new role.  Although there is now a plethora of new and developing roles within emergency and urgent care, most have been introduced to meet local needs with little or no formal critical evaluation. Those that have received evaluation or review have not been replicated in a standardised manner in other parts of the emergency and urgent care pathway within the UK. The roles of the Emergency Nurse Practitioner and Advanced Clinical/Nurse Practitioner, for example, both lack any universally accepted definition or standard and have been interpreted in a number of ways and vary significantly in terms of their preparation, scope of practice and potential impact on services.

Many of the roles that have been introduced have tended to focus on tasks and have been carved out of existing roles e.g. phlebotomist, ECG technician and chest pain nurse. Although these restrictive roles have definite advantages in terms of their practical application within emergency and urgent care, e.g. increased expertise within a specific clinical pathway, easier to recruit and cheaper to employ etc; they all have real disadvantages. Their practical application causes additional process steps which may lead to increased clinical risk within and between care transitions, delays and less flexibility within the available workforce. It is therefore important to consider whether developing generic staff and nurse and allied professional clinicians may be better than specific, but role restricted staff.

The development of alternative roles to that of the doctor has become a global trend in the last few decades particularly in the United Kingdom where there has been extensive remodelling and re-engineering of clinical teams. A substantial number of generic roles now exist including; Emergency Nurse and Department Practitioners, Advanced Practitioners, Specialist Nurses, and more latterly, Consultant Nurses. Their introduction has been affected by an imperative to modernise medical careers, reduce the working hours of doctors in line with the European Working Time Directive, increased patient expectations and choice, and the achievement of national targets as well as the need for less waiting. Although there are polarised views regarding their potential worth across health disciplines and agreed role definitions remain a challenge, these competency based roles have enabled nurses and allied health professionals to work more autonomously within emergency and urgent care settings such as Urgent Care Centres and Walk-in Centres. In many cases practitioners can now see, treat, admit and/or discharge patients across the acuity spectrum from those patients with relatively minor problems, through to those attending with life threatening illnesses and injuries. Some hospitals within the United Kingdom e.g. Heart of England Foundation Trust, have embraced these new roles to the point where almost half of all their emergency admissions are now treated exclusively by a non-medical workforce.

 

Consultant Nurse role
The Consultant Nurse is a nurse leader who usually practices with a high level of clinical autonomy, seeing patients with undifferentiated and undiagnosed problems. In addition to expert clinical practice the role usually encompasses an audit and research component, service and practice development responsibilities and education and training. The main advantage associated with the role is the retention of highly experienced and knowledgeable individuals at the nurse/patient interface combined with the role of the expert practitioner.  Limitations of the role centre on the individual nurse’s scope and freedom to practice which is often locally determined and the lack of standardisation around preparation. These factors will ultimately limit the role and its potential to impact on services and its long term existence. There is little available evidence related to the role of the Consultant Nurse with regard to its impact on services and clinical care.      

 

Emergency Nurse Practitioner and Physiotherapy Practitioner
The scope of an ENP is usually limited to the care of ‘minor’ injuries, such as extremity bone and soft tissue injuries. More recently ENPs have developed their scope of practice to include care and treatment of patients with ‘minor’ illnesses and evidence would suggest that they are as safe as senior house officers, although consultation times are likely to be longer. (1-3) Similar findings around consultation times were found by Horrocks et al, in a systematic review of nurses working in primary care. (4) However, patients were more satisfied with care from a nurse practitioner than the doctor, with no differences in health outcomes. The influence of nurse practitioners within emergency and urgent care has steadily increased since their inception several decades ago and are now included in the College of Emergency Medicine’s strategy and guidance for emergency medicine. (5)   It is important to note that many of the studies comparing ENPs with doctors are not necessarily comparing identical variables e.g. ENPs are usually involved in the whole episode of care whereas medical staff tend to transfer the responsibility for discharge to a nurse or other professional.

Although the literature related to the role of the ED Physiotherapy Practitioner (EDPP) is limited, available evidence would suggest high levels of patient satisfaction around four domains of practice; advice and information giving, explanation of the results of the assessment, what would happen next, and the overall care given. (6-7) EDPPs have been shown to be as effective as ENPs and ED doctors of all grades for patients with musculoskeletal problems, soft tissues injuries, fractures and dislocations. (8)

 

Advanced Nurse/Clinical Practitioner
The Advanced Nurse/Clinical Practitioner role is still a relatively new concept within emergency and urgent care but is gaining recognition nationally and internationally for enhancing services and improving patient choice. Recently it has been defined more precisely by the Nursing and Midwifery Council as an experienced nurse working autonomously as a clinical expert with the ability to diagnose patients from a diverse and undetermined caseload. The influence of this highly educated workforce on services is yet to be determined but many ANPs or ACPs now see and treat patients across the whole acuity spectrum. Further research is required to determine this influence but initial findings may suggest that they are as safe as middle grade doctors, Consultant Emergency Physicians and General Practitioners working in Emergency Departments within their scope of practice. The limitations of the role centre on the individual nurse’s scope and freedom to practice which is often locally determined by medical staff and the lack of standardisation and insufficient direction and agreement from the Nursing & Midwifery Council around preparation. Again, these factors will ultimately limit the role and its potential to impact on services and its long term existence.

 

Emergency Department Practitioner
Ongoing issues with regard to the recruitment and retention of an adequately trained and experienced resuscitation room workforce capable of recognising and responding to physiological instability in high dependency patients has led to the introduction of Operating Department Practitioners in some EDs in the United Kingdom. In creating this new role known as an Emergency Department Practitioner (EDP), it was hoped that the advanced skills developed in the operating room environment over the last decade could be applied equally to the resuscitation room. Initial evidence would suggest that traditional ED staff value this new role. A Delphi consensus study undertaken by Empson et al assessed the impact on clinical care among staff who had worked in an urban ED pre and post introduction of seven EDPs. Additional benefits were emphasised by staff covering a number of issues including the maintenance, availability and stocking of equipment and the care of unstable resuscitation room patients. The impact of EDPs on the role of traditional ED staff was explored leading to a belief that resuscitation room safety and ongoing patient monitoring had improved significantly as had the care of critically ill and injured patients who required advanced airway interventions. (9)

111-1Novel therapies in severe sepsis

Written by Dr Gavin Perkins, September 2007.
Updated by Dr Ron Daniels, October 2009

Back to Knowledge Week contents

Introduction

The earlier articles in this series have defined the major impact that sepsis has on health in our community and the complex pathophysiological processes involved in the development of sepsis and sepsis-related organ dysfunction.

Significant advances have been made in defining new treatments for sepsis in the past decade.  These include the use of early goal directed therapy1 and activated Protein C2 to mention but two.

Improvements in our understanding of the pathophysiology involved in sepsis are helping to open up new avenues for exploring therapeutic interventions.  This article will provide an oversight to some of the new strategies being investigated in the fight against sepsis related morbidity and mortality.


Early recognition of sepsis and risk stratification

The diagnosis of sepsis can be difficult in that the clinical signs of the sepsis (tachycardia, leucocytosis, tachypnoea, and pyrexia) often overlap with other non-infectious causes of systemic inflammation such as trauma, surgery and hypoxia3.  Microbiological cultures are often used to distinguish sepsis from non-infectious conditions. However, this method lacks sensitivity and specificity, and there is often a substantial time delay between collecting the sample and obtaining a definitive result.  Delays in diagnosis and treatment of sepsis can result in rapid progression to circulatory collapse, multiple organ failure, and eventually death. Therefore, accurate and timely diagnosis of sepsis has the potential to limit morbidity, reduce costs, and improve patients' outcome4.


Early detection of micro-organisms5

Blood cultures play a central role in the diagnosis of blood stream infection in today’s clinical practice.  In the United Kingdom, organisations are obliged to monitor and report on positive cultures for methicillin-resistant S.aureus (MRSA). However, the traditional blood culture tests are slow (usually taking several days), and are not particularly sensitive (particularly if the patient has already received antibiotics). 

Newer techniques such as DNA-based techniques (hybridisation probes and PCR-based detection) or protein based detection by mass spectroscopy are aimed at rapid identification of bacteria and provide results within 2 hours after the first signal of growth in conventional blood cultures.  These molecular biology techniques have been extended to allow the direct detection of pathogens in blood without the need for initial culture.  Interpretation of the results from these assays are complex as they detect the presence of DNA rather than living pathogens, which could arise from contamination or background DNA in the blood.  At present a major limitation of these techniques is the lack of simultaneous provision of antimicrobial susceptibility, however the use of assays to detect bacterial resistance genes are growing and are already in use in clinical practice for organisms such as MRSA.  Further evaluation of these techniques is required, although with time it is anticipated that they will replace the current conventional microbiological techniques for the detection of infections.


Early recognition of sepsis syndrome

A number of circulating inflammatory markers have been investigated as tools to facilitate the early recognition of sepsis.  These include pro-calcitonin; IL-6; direct measurement of endotoxin, TREM-1, lipoprotein binding protein and triggering receptor on myeloid cells6, 7.  Pro-calcitonin has shown the most promise as a biomarker of early sepsis.  It fulfills several criteria of clinical needs: it responds both to infection and severity of inflammation and thus has an impact on therapy. Recent studies indicate that antibiotic treatment can also be guided by procalcitonin8,9. However a recent systematic review of trials of critically ill patients with sepsis concluded that procalcitonin cannot reliably differentiate sepsis from other non-infectious causes of systemic inflammatory response syndrome in critically ill adult patients arguing against the routine use of  procalcitonin test in critical care settings10.

Host response to infection

Genetics

Observational studies in identical twins have shown that genetic factors are a major determinants of susceptibility to death from infectious disease11.  Single-nucleotide polymorphisms (involving single base-pair alterations) have been described in genes controlling the host response to infection such as alterations in TNF receptors, interleukin-1 receptors, Fc-? receptors, coagulation factors and Toll-Like Receptors (TLRs)12,13. As an example, a polymorphism of the TLR 4 gene confers increased susceptibility to overwhelming gram-negative infection. Polymorphisms in cytokine genes may determine the concentrations of inflammatory and antiinflammatory cytokines produced and may influence whether persons have marked hyperinflammatory or hypoinflammatory responses to infection. For example, the risk of death among patients with sepsis has been linked to genetic polymorphisms for TNF-a and TNF-ß14.

Trials examining the effect of polymorphisms in patients with sepsis are under way (e.g. GENOSEPT15). Such polymorphisms may ultimately be used to identify patients at high risk for the development of sepsis and organ dysfunction during infection. More precise categorization of patients based on genetic background is likely to lead to individualized targeted treatment. Future therapeutic trials as well as actual treatment regimens for patients with sepsis are likely to be designed to target specific genotypes and associated cellular responses, maximizing clinical response and patient safety.


New therapeutic interventions

Clinical trials of treatments for sepsis are difficult because of the heterogeneity of patients and the high rates of culture-negative sepsis. New insights into the pathophysiology of sepsis and sepsis related organ failure are providing opportunities for developing novel therapeutic interventions targeting specific pathways from infection to sepsis to multi-organ failure have been expanding16.  A recent review of sepsis published in the New England Journal of Medicine outlined several potential therapeutic targets and the results of clinical trials with these agents17. This was supplemented by a literature search of MEDLINE for papers about novel treatments for sepsis published from January 2006 to August 2007. A selection of the potentially more promising therapies are provided in Table 1 below, although this list is not meant by any means to be exhaustive. The precise impact of these agents in the battle to improve outcome from sepsis remain to be determined.

Table 1: Selection of the potentially more promising therapies for Sepsis

Pathway Target Treatment Reference
Host pathogen interaction LPS Anti-endotoxin  18
  Toll receptors TLR agonists and antagonists  17, 19
  Neutrophil G-CSF  20, 21
  Cell adhesion Leukocyte-endothelial interactions  22
Inflammatory cascade TNF alpha Anti TNF  23, 24
  IL1 beta IL1-ra  25
  IL-6 IL-6 antagonist  
  Prostagrlandins, leukotrienes Ibuprofen
High dose steroids		  26
 27
  Platelet activating factor PAF acetyl hydrolase  28
  Isoprenoid intermediates Statins  29, 30
  High-Mobility Group B1 Protein Ethyl pyruvate  31
  Oxidants N-acetylcysteine  32
Microcirculation Microcirculatory dysfunction Prostacyclin  30, 33

Coagulation Protein C Activated protein C  4
  Protein S Protein S  34
  Antithrombin III Antithrombin III  35

Apoptosis  White cell apoptosis Anticaspases  37
  Epithelial cells Anticaspases  37


Polyclonal immunoglobulins

Intravenous immunoglobulin therapy is nothing new. Studies investigating the application of ‘standard’ IgG immunoglobulins have not been encouraging38. IgM polyclonal immunoglobulin, however, may more accurately mimic the primary response to infection in humans, and it may be effective in promoting bacterial labelling and subsequent lysis in vivo. Two recent meta-analyses suggest that IgM may be worthy of further investigation39,40.


ß2 agonists

ß agonists may have beneficial effects in sepsis, particularly in acute lung injury, through reductions in cytokine and free radical production, increased surfactant production and a possible role in promoting lung repair. Inhaled ß2 agonists have been shown to improve pulmonary mechanics and reduce extravascular lung water41. A funded multi-centre study, the BALTI 2 study, is currently recruiting in the U.K to assess possible outcome benefits.

High mobility group box protein

High mobility box group protein (HMGB-1) is a potent pro-inflammatory mediator, appearing late in the process of the development of sepsis. Animal models have shown that infusions of HMGB-1 mimic sepsis, and blockade of HMGB-1 reduces organ failure and death. Human studies also demonstrate elevated levels of HMGB-1 in patients destined to die as opposed to survivors, making targeting this pathway attractive for sepsis therapy42.

111-1Organisation of trauma services

Compiled by Dr Mark Nash, February 2010.


How should trauma services be organised?
Guidance/Tools
Reports and Consultation Documents
Websites
References
Related Management Briefings

How should trauma services be organised?

In 1988, the Royal College of Surgeons produced a report into the care of the multiply injured patient.  They found major deficiencies in the care of this population of patients and subsequently produced a series of recommendations. As a consequence of this report, the system of Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS), devised in the USA, was adopted for all those dealing with major trauma patients (1).
A joint report from the British Orthopaedic Society and the Royal College of Surgeons in 2000 reinforced the previous points, including: the need for nationally coordinated standards of care, national trauma systems with a hub, and spoke network and systematic audit to monitor the improvement (2).
Despite this, the NCEPOD report in 2007, ‘Trauma who cares?’, highlighted ongoing failings in the system and recommended the development of regionalised trauma centres, staffed by senior clinicians with access to specialist facilities 24/7,  in a similar fashion to those operating in the USA (3).
The Darzi report into all medical services in London, and specifically the treatment of the multiply injured patient, has seen the first major step forward in adoption of the trauma centre system within the UK by a specific health care provider group (4).
Not only do the clinical guidelines and protocols for the management of patients with multiple injuries need to be developed, but also the infrastructure and organisation of all those areas of the NHS who will play a role in the patient care pathway, from the pre-hospital, through the hospital and finally into the rehabilitation phase. This rehabilitation phase is critical in any system’s ability to process patients through it and to optimise their outcome (5).
In 2009, the Royal College of Surgeons produced a report to assist regional commissioners in the development of trauma centres. This comprehensive document provides not only an explanation of what trauma services are about, but also gives recommendations on the commissioning process and recommended standards in all aspects of trauma care (6).

111-1Paediatric emergency care

Compiled by Dr Ffion Davies, February 2010.


What is Paediatric Emergency Care?
Guidance/Tools
Reports and Consultation Documents
Websites
References
Related Management Briefings

What is Paediatric Emergency Care?

Paediatric Emergency Care simply describes emergency and urgent care (i.e. all unscheduled medical care) for children and young people, up to adulthood. In health services, the majority of providers use the 16th birthday to define the transition to becoming an adult.

All frontline healthcare practitioners should be competent to recognise a sick child, communicate with children and their parents effectively, and detect any child welfare concerns. Very useful resources have recently been published by the Department of Health (England)1 and the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence2. The Resuscitation Council and the Advanced Life Support Group both provide courses (1-2 days) to teach management of a sick child in the first hour of care. Dealing with patients who are not yet legally adults requires an understanding of issues of consent and confidentiality, for which there is good guidance written by the General Medical Council3.

Pre-school children are heavy users of emergency care services, especially urgent General Practitioner appointments and NHS Direct. Children are less likely to require ambulance transportation than adults. They have much shorter lengths of hospital stay. This is because deterioration and recovery from illness or injury are faster than for adults. For children under 2 years it is also because the early stages of serious illness are difficult to discriminate from the minor, self-limiting viral illnesses which are very common at this age. It is therefore appropriate that facilities are provided for observation by skilled healthcare professionals for these few hours. General Practitioners may be able to arrange follow-up later the same day or the next morning. Out of hours services and emergency departments need access to Short Stay Paediatric Assessment Units. Children’s wards in acute hospitals serve this purpose, but increasingly a shift of concept towards rapid turnover with senior doctor support, will become necessary. The Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health has published a very simple guide to this4. Face-to-face assessment of children is much more reliable than telephone consultation.

For a general picture of paediatric emergency care within UK emergency departments, an editorial from 2008 is still current5. For professional and service standards for paediatric emergency care providers, a straightforward document is available from the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health website. A new edition is planned in 20116.

document.description: Part of the National Knowledge Week for Foundation Doctors 2007. Reviewed May 2009.
document.body:
111-1Pain (assessment and management of)

Written by Dr Andrew Newton, July 2007.
Reviewed by Rachael Boddy, Spr Emergency Medicine, May 2009.

PDF version of this topic

Back to Knowledge Week contents

Introduction

Pain is an unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage, or it is described in terms of such damage.

Pain is always subjective. Each individual learns the application of the word through experiences related to injury in early life. (The International Association for the Study of Pain). 

Key Learning Points 

  1. The pain that patients experience is often not well recognised or assessed by either doctors or nurses. As a result pain is frequently under treated.
  2. Pain is a complex interaction of physiological and psychological responses. Treatment should address all these issues and so should consist of reassurance and advice as well as treating the cause and giving pharmacological agents.
  3. Different types of pain exist (e.g somatic, visceral, neuropathic etc.). The cause of pain (diagnosis) needs to be sought. However, treatment of the patient’s pain can begin before a diagnosis is made.
  4. Physiological responses to pain (an increased pulse, blood pressure, respiratory rate etc) are undesirable in ill or injured patients.
  5. The QUESTT approach (designed for paediatric use) is a very useful concept. (Reference 1)
  6. After analgesia has been administered its effect must be assessed by formally re-evaluating the patient’s pain. Repeated pain scores should be undertaken. When undertaking procedures on patients the good practitioner should anticipate rather than react to the patient’s pain.
  7. Simple drugs do work well if used appropriately however for severe pain stronger analgesia is required early. React to the patients pain by prescribing appropriately as determined by their pain score (References 2 and 3)
  8. If Intravenous opiates (eg Morphine Sulphate) are used; dosage should be titrated against pain with small sequential aliquots given until pain relief is achieved.
  9. For pain that is going to be ongoing analgesia needs to be given by the clock rather than on demand, this can then be supplemented by top-up doses.
  10. Chronic pain management is a complex problem; specialist advice and multi-disciplinary input are vital to its correct management.

More Detailed information

The QUESTT approach to pain management was first described in the 1980’s.  This is a mnemonic which highlights the key actions that should be taken by a practitioner dealing with a patient in pain; (Reference 1)

Q. Question the patient about their pain.
U. Use a pain rating scale.
E. Evaluate the patient’s status by observing their behaviour and by recording vital signs.
S. Secure patient (and carer) involvement
T. Take the cause of the pain into account.
T. Take action and treat the pain.

A patient in severe pain needs to have that pain treated rapidly. It makes little sense to try and treat severe pain with simple analgesic medication. The appropriate use of pain rating scales facilitates rational matching of analgesic prescription to the patient’s needs (References 2 and 3)

There are a large number of different assessment tools available for measuring pain. Broadly speaking, assessment tools can be classed into two groups; those that are observer dependent and those that rely on a patient’s self report of their pain. The ability of a patient to use a self reporting scale is dependent upon their age and also on their cognitive function. Many rating scales work at their best when a patient has been taught to use them appropriately before they have pain; patients presenting do novo with an acute onset of severe pain frequently rate their pain as “10/10”; therefore observational pain assessment tools often have a role in this particular circumstance especially for the evaluation of pain in young children (Reference 4). Pain Scores are very helpful in evaluating response to pain relief.

Practitioners should familiarise themselves with local pain management protocols. It is best to become familiar with a few drugs and to use them well having a full understanding of the drug, its effects, possible interactions and adverse events, its contra indications and the appropriate methods for administration. All practitioners should have a familiarity with the following drugs – Paracetamol, Non-steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs (including Ibuprofen, Diclofenac), oral opiates (including codeine and dihydrocodeine) and injectable opiates (including morphine sulphate and diamorphine). (References 5 and 6)

The management of chronic pain is a very complex and challenging subject. The early involvement of pain management specialists and multi disciplinary teams is highly recommended. The Cancer pain relief programme of the World Health Organisation (WHO) has advocated a three step “analgesic ladder” in an attempt to improve the management of pain due to cancer. (Reference 7)

References

1. Wong D, Baker C. The QUEST approach to pain management. General Paediatric Nursing 1988;14(1):9–17.

2. College of Emergency Medicine Clinical Effectiveness Committee. Guidelines for Management of Pain in Adults. 2004. [full text]

3. College of Emergency Medicine Clinical Effectiveness Committee. Guideline for Management of Pain in Children. 2004 [full text]

4. Stewart B, et al. Validation of the Alder Hey Triage Pain Score. Archives of Disease in Childhood 2004;89(7):625–30. [abstract]

5. Clinical Knowledge Summaries, NSAIDs – prescribing issues: Prescibing an NSAID (standard or coxib). 16 June 2008. [full text]

6. National Guideline Clearinghouse. Use of non steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs: an update for clinicians. A scientific statement from the American Heart Association (NGC summary). March 2007. [summary]

7. World Health Organisation (WHO) Analgesic Ladder for the management of Cancer Pain [full text]

Relevant Standards (College of Emergency Medicine)

Patients in severe pain (pain score 7 to 10) should receive appropriate analgesia, according to local guidelines,
50% within 20 mins of arrival or triage whichever is the earliest.
75% within 30 mins of arrival or triage whichever is the earliest.
98% within 60 mins of arrival or triage whichever is the earliest.

Patients with moderate pain (pain score 4 to 6) should be offered or receive analgesia, according to local guidelines,
75% within 30 mins of arrival or triage whichever is the earliest.
90% within 60 mins of arrival or triage whichever is the earliest.

Re-evaluation
90% of patients with severe pain should have documented evidence of re-evaluation and action within 30 minutes of receiving the first dose of analgesic.
75% of patients with moderate pain should have documented evidence of re-evaluation and action within 60 minutes of receiving the first dose of analgesic.

 

Back to Knowledge Week contents

document.title: Paracetamol and ibuprofen for the treatment of fever in children: the PITCH randomised controlled trial
document.publisher: NIHR Evaluation, Trials and Studies Coordinating Centre (NETSCC)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,CLINICAL LIBRARY,PRESCRIBING,SELECTED SYMPTOMS,OTHER PRESCRIBING,SPECIFIC PAEDIATRIC SYMPTOMS,PUO > 5 DAYS,SPECIFIC DRUGS]]>
document.body:
Conclusion: Doctors, nurses and parents who want to use medicines to treat young children who are unwell with fever should be advised to use ibuprofen first and to consider the relative risks (inadvertently exceeding the maximum recommended dose) and benefits (extra 2.5 hours without fever) of using paracetamol plus ibuprofen over 24 hours. Pragmatically, we speculate that if a child remains unwell after a first dose of ibuprofen, subsequent use of both medicines will be more effective than either monotherapy. However, if two medicines are used, we recommend that all dose times are carefully recorded to avoid accidentally exceeding the maximum recommended dose. Manufacturers should consider supplying blank charts for this purpose. The economic analysis shows that the use of both medicines should not be discouraged on the basis of cost to either parents or the NHS. Parents and clinicians should be aware that fever is a relatively short-lived symptom, but may have more serious prognostic implications than the other common symptom presentations of childhood.

Method: The trial design was a single-centre (multisite), individually randomised, blinded, three-arm trial comparing paracetamol and ibuprofen together with paracetamol or ibuprofen separately.

Results: Please see full report for details of results.

Citation: Hay AD, Redmond NM, Costelloe C, Montgomery AA, Fletcher M, Hollinghurst S et al.Paracetamol and ibuprofen for the treatment of fever in children: the PITCH randomised controlled trial.Health Technology Assessment 2009;13(27):1 - 186

document.description: Part of the National Knowledge Week for Sepsis Bundles, updated in October 2009.
document.body:
111-1Pathophysiology of sepsis

Written by Dr Ron Daniels, September 2007.
Updated by Dr Ron Daniels, October 2009.

Back to Knowledge Week contents


Here we shall explore in some detail some of the changes occurring in sepsis. These changes occur at various levels- cellular, humoral (changes in circulating compounds or protein factors) and in terms of organ function.

It is increasingly understood that multiple interacting pathways are involved in the systemic response to infection, and that to attempt to examine any one pathway in isolation is simplistic.

 
The immune system

Sepsis is an exaggeration of the body’s normal response to infection, and is almost always in response to bacterial or fungal infection. Micro-organisms (eg bacteria, viruses, fungi) can cause various immune responses, each of which have a role to play in the pathophysiology of sepsis.

Even considering the immune response as a whole, we cannot view it as a single entity. It is clear that there is a biphasic immune response in sepsis. Initially, the typical pro-inflammatory response predominates, but in the latter phases, anti-inflammatory responses are also seen- sometimes referred to as the Compensatory anti-inflammatory response (CARS)- with associated relative immunosuppression.

Broadly, the immune system includes the complement system, white blood cells and the antibodies they produce. Inherited variations exist between individuals- for example, genetic polymorphisms of a receptor known as the Toll-like Receptor (TLR) predispose individuals to overwhelming infections with gram-negative organisms.
 
The immune system may be subdivided into the innate (‘inbuilt’) and adaptive (or ‘learned’) systems.

 

Activation of the immune system

The most studied means of early activation is via bacterial proteins binding to Toll-like Receptors (TLRs) on immune cells and some endothelial cells. The effects are multiple, and the following list is not exhaustive:

Cytokine release brings about stimulation of production, activation and migration of various white blood cell types in addition to amplifying other pathways. The release of molecules such as active oxygen species and proteases assist with bacterial cell killing.

The complement system is a group of plasma proteins that are usually inactive. These proteins are activated either via non-specific interactions with bacterial or viral cell surfaces, or by the presence of antibodies to a pathogen (invading organism) resulting in the formation of antigen-antibody complexes (an antigen is a protein present on the surface of an invading microorganism or an infected cell). The complement proteins activate each other in a ‘cascade’ of reactions, to form part of the body’s defence system against micro-organisms. In other words, once one complement protein is activated, it activates the next in turn and so on.

The activated complement cascade releases many fragments, such as C3b and C5a, mediating activation of leukocytes (white blood cells), attracting them to the site of infection where the various types of white blood cell can directly attack the organism (phagocytes, cytotoxic T lymphocytes), identify it for attack by others (antigen presenting cells, B lymphocytes), ‘remember’ it in case of future infection (memory cells, B lymphocytes), and cause the increased production and chemotaxis of more T helper cells.

The complement system also causes mast cell degranulation, which causes the release of histamine. Histamine increases vascular permeability and vasodilatation (see below).

 

White blood cells

Phagocytes (neutrophils, monocytes, macrophages) can recognise micro-organisms directly as well as with the aid of complement or antibodies. The phagocyte engulfs the micro-organism and digests it, releasing active metabolites and inflammatory mediators. These mediators further the process of inflammation, vasodilatation and capillary leakage.

Lymphocytes can be activated directly or by other white blood cells known as antigen presenting cells. Lymphocytes are subdivided into B  and T lymphocytes. B lymphocytes ‘remember’ pathogens or microbes and create antibodies to them (antibodies are proteins that identify the target for immunological attack, and stimulate phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages or activate the complement system). T lymphocytes are divided into cytotoxic T cells and helper T cells. Cytotoxic T cells are activated by antigens (proteins on the surface of cells- their ‘signature’) on infected cells. The cytotoxic T cell destroys the cell by secreting perforins which create pores in the cell, making it burst. Helper T cells are activated by macrophages presenting antigen to them. The helper T cell then secretes cytokines (chemical messengers), which cause increased production of B lymphocytes and cytotoxic T lymphocytes.

The inflammatory process is, therefore, a complex system of interconnecting pathways and cascades designed to identify and destroy pathogens, and to remember the ‘signature’ of the pathogens so that a more effective response can be mounted should the need arise again. Micro-organisms can also directly damage cells causing further release of inflammatory mediators. The actions of some of these mediators are summarised below.

 

Mediator  Source  Main Effect 
Histamine  Mast cells, basophils, platelets  Vasodilatation, increased vascular permeability
Serotonin  Platelets  Increased vascular permeability, platelet aggregation
Prostaglandins   All leucocytes, platelets, endothelial cells Most cause vasodilatation  Thromboxane - vasoconstriction
Leukotrienes  All leucocytes  Vasoconstriction, bronchospasm, increased vascular permeability
Platelet activating factor (PAF) All leucocytes, platelets, endothelial cells  Platelet aggregation and degranulation, vasodilatation, increased vascular permeability, leukocyte adherence
Nitric oxide (NO)  Endothelial cells, macrophages, platelets   Vasodilatation
Cytokines (interleukin eg IL1, Tumour necrosis factor TNF)  Macrophages, lymphocytes  Vasodilatation, fever, lethargy, attracts leucocytes
Kinin system
(Bradykinin) 		 Circulates in plasma inactive  Increased vascular permeability, vasodilatation
Complement System   Cascade of inactive plasma proteins Leukocyte activation, phagocytosis
C3a and C5a cause increased vascular permeability and vasodilatation


The Vascular Endothelium

Vascular endothelium (the lining of the blood vessels), particularly in capillaries, plays a pivotal role in the initiation, mediation and pathology of sepsis. Active endothelium allows immune cell adhesion and facilitates migration. Nitric oxide (NO) is secreted, causing vascular smooth muscle relaxation. Collateral channels open up, reducing both pressure in and flow through capillary networks and worsening organ hypoperfusion.

Inflammation

Inflammation is a protective response intended to eliminate the cause of injury and any necrotic tissue present as a result of the injury. In this case the injury is the presence of a pathogen or infection. Inflammation has 3 stages:

  1. Vasodilatation - increased blood flow, causing phagocytes, clotting factors, antibodies etc. to be circulated to the area
  2. Increased permeability of blood vessels – allows plasma proteins to leave the circulation and access the site
  3. Migration of leucocytes to site of injury (discussed above)

In severe sepsis the processes caused by the immune response and resulting inflammation are disordered and out of control. A massive systemic reaction occurs and an excess of inflammatory mediators are released, causing an overwhelming physiological response which causes tissue damage and organ dysfunction.


Vasodilatation

The majority of the inflammatory mediators cause massive vasodilatation, which is one of the main causes of tachycardia, hypotension and inadequate organ perfusion in severe sepsis. In the early stages this may be recognised as oliguria, altered mental status etc. Vasodilatation can also lead to hypothermia. 
 

Vasodilatation results in a relative hypovolaemia (greater potential capacity of the circulatory system, same circulating volume). An additional contributor to vasodilatation is a relative unresponsiveness of the vessels to circulating catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine)- the mechanisms for this are unclear.
 

Increased vascular permeability

A number of the inflammatory mediators also cause increased vascular permeability, such that the blood vessels, especially capillaries, become ‘leaky’. This causes intravascular volume to leak into the extravascular space, resulting in oedema of the tissues and loss of circulating volume. Together with the ‘pooling’ of the blood due to vasodilatation, this causes further tachycardia, hypotension and shock. This adds an absolute hypovolaemia (loss of circulating volume) to compound the relative hypovolaemia of vasodilatation.

The combination of collateral pathways and oedema (effectively a barrier to diffusion of oxygen and nutrients) contribute to organ dysfunction.

 

Changes in the circulation

The immune and inflammatory responses cause an increased oxygen demand from the tissues. The body attempts to supply the oxygen demand by increasing delivery. Oxygen delivery depends on 2 factors; the oxygen content of blood and cardiac output.


As can be seen from the above equations, oxygen content depends on haemoglobin concentration (Hb), oxygen saturation (SaO2) and partial pressure of oxygen in arterial blood (PaO2). The body tries to improve oxygen content by increasing respiratory rate. Therapies attempt to maximise oxygen content by ensuring the absence of anaemia and optimal arterial haemoglobin oxygen saturation.

Oxygen demand can increase up to 12 fold in sepsis, but cardiac output can only increase up to 5 fold (less in the elderly) to compensate for this. The body first attempts to increase cardiac output by increasing heart rate, but heart rate can only increase up to about 150 beats/min (varies between individuals) giving an approximate doubling of cardiac output. When heart rate becomes greater than this, there is a decrease in cardiac filling time and a subsequent decrease in cardiac output. To further increase cardiac output, stroke volume must increase.

Stroke volume (a determinant of cardiac output) is determined by 3 factors:

Preload – filling pressure, or how much blood is present in the heart before it contracts. We can estimate this using central venous pressure (CVP). It can be decreased in sepsis due to vasodilatation and increased vascular permeability causing a relative decrease in intravascular volume leading to a decrease in preload. On its own, this would lead to a decrease in cardiac output.

Afterload – related to systemic vascular resistance (SVR), sepsis causes a decrease in SVR and a decrease in afterload. In the absence of failure, this leads to an increase in cardiac output.

Contractility – how hard the heart contracts. This is decreased in sepsis due to reduced filling of the heart, hypoxaemia and acidosis. There is an additional, as yet unidentified circulating factor in severe sepsis which directly reduces contractility.

Therefore in severe sepsis there is a balance of factors reducing the cardiac output (reduced preload, acidosis) and factors increasing it (the baroreceptor reflex detecting a lowered blood pressure, reduced afterload). In the early stages the cardiac output often increases in an attempt to maintain blood pressure and due to vasodilatation, providing the tissues with much-needed extra oxygen. During the later stages, however, these compensatory mechanisms become exhausted and the cardiac output may begin to fall. In turn, tissue perfusion and oxygen supply becomes compromised and the spiral downward to multi-organ failure ensues.
 
If oxygen demand of the tissues is not met by oxygen delivery then anaerobic respiration occurs and lactic acid is produced as a by-product. Lactic acid is measured as serum lactate. Therefore raised lactate indicates a failure of peripheral perfusion and oxygen delivery. Increased lactate causes a metabolic acidosis, which is compensated for initially by hyperventilation (another reason we see a raised respiratory rate). Increased lactate causes an increased respiratory rate, cardiac depression and altered mental state.
 

The lung in sepsis

Increased vascular permeability in pulmonary capillaries causes pulmonary oedema (fluid leaking into the lung alveoli) and infiltrates, including proteins and activated neutrophils. Surfactant production is reduced. Later, mononuclear cells infiltrate, type II pneumocytes proliferate and interstitial fibrosis may develop. The changes lead to arterial hypoxaemia (a low partial pressure of oxygen in the bloodstream), reduced respiratory compliance (the lungs are stiffer) and increased work of breathing (it requires more work and energy to breath). This syndrome is known as acute lung injury (ALI) or, in its more severe form, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and can lead to respiratory failure requiring ventilation.


The kidney in sepsis

Hypotension contributes to oliguria. However, acute renal failure in sepsis is a relatively common occurrence, and is not always explained by the demonstration of prolonged periods of hypotension. Although the term ‘acute tubular necrosis’ is used, histological changes are normally absent, and most patients surviving an episode of severe sepsis recover their renal function. Nitric oxide, and its effects on mitochondrial oxygen transport, have been postulated as partly responsible for renal dysfunction in sepsis.

 

The effect of sepsis on temperature control

Body temperature is usually maintained at 36.8 0C +/- 0.70C in order to maintain normal enzyme and cell function. Temperature is controlled by the hypothalamus. The hypothalamus monitors body temperature and regulates heat loss from the skin: by vasoconstriction/vasodilatation of cutaneous blood vessels, sweating, erection of body hair causing trapping of air, and by increasing heat production (shivering). 

Fever is a temporary elevation in the body’s thermoregulatory set point. Temperature is regulated by the hypothalamus in response to prostaglandin E2 (PgE2). PgE2 release is triggered by pyrogens. There are 2 types of pyrogens: endogenous (made by the body) and exogenous (from outside the body or from microbes). Exogenous pyrogens are microbial products and toxins, such as gram-negative endotoxins. Exogenous pyrogens bind to macrophages causing release of endogenous cytokines. Endogenous pyrogens are cytokines, such as IL1, IL6, TNF -a. These cytokines further enhance production of PgE2.

 

Effects on coagulation

Activation of coagulation

The coagulation cascade is activated by damage to the capillary endothelium (the inner lining of the capillary), caused by pathogens and a number of inflammatory mediators. The coagulation cascade involves many circulating factors in a cascade mechanism, where one factor activates the next in turn, resulting in the creation of a fibrin plug.

In health, a delicate balance exists between coagulation and fibrinolysis (the breakdown of fibrin clots) to ensure that clotting occurs only where it is needed. In severe sepsis, this balance becomes disordered.

In sepsis multiple cytokines, including interleukins 1 and 6 (IL1, IL6) and tumour necrosis factor alpha (TNF-?) induce the expression of tissue factor (TF) on endothelial cells and monocytes, initiating coagulation. Microthrombi form and build up in the capillaries. These microthrombi eventually obstruct the capillaries, compromising blood supply and leading to tissue necrosis. When these capillaries are involved in the supply of end organs, this contributes to multi-organ failure.

Inhibitors of coagulation and suppression of fibrinolysis

Fibrinolysis is the breakdown of fibrin by plasmin. Plasmin is formed when tissue plasminogen activating factor (t-PA) triggers the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin. Excessive fibrinolysis is normally inhibited by plasminogen activator inhibitor (PAI -1) and thrombin activatable fibrinolysis inhibitor (TAF1).

In sepsis PAI-1 levels increase, while t-PA and plasminogen decrease, causing a decrease in fibrinolysis.  There are reduced levels of the natural inhibitors of coagulation, Antithrombin III and activated protein C. Anti-thrombin forms complexes with thrombin, factors Xa, XIIa, XIa and IXa inactivating them before being removed by the liver. Activated protein C inactivates cofactors Va and VIIIa impeding the clotting process, as well as enhancing fibrinolysis by neutralising PAI-1 and by accelerating clot breakdown. Activated protein C also has a direct anti-inflammatory effect, decreasing cytokine production and inhibiting leukocyte attachment to endothelium. This is the basis of the use of recombinant activated protein C in severe sepsis.

Disseminated intravascular Coagulation (DIC)

As explained above, sepsis triggers the coagulation cascade. This widespread clotting causes consumption of platelets, clotting factors and fibrinogen, causing impaired coagulation and therefore increases risk of bleeding. Clotting tests such as the activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) and international normalised ratio (INR) are therefore raised and fibrinogen levels are decreased. After the increased coagulation and fibrin formation there is secondary fibrinolysis resulting in increased fibrin degradation products (FDPs) including D-Dimer, which can be measured.

DIC can cause bleeding, large vessel thrombosis, haemorrhagic tissue necrosis and formation of microthrombi- all further contributors to organ failure. The patients will bruise easily and bleed from various sites: cannula sites, surgical wounds, gastro-intestinal tract, lungs and urinary tract.

The treatment of DIC is simple though not always effective- treat the underlying sepsis, prevent bleeding (eg. Pressure to bleeding points, H2 receptor antagonists to reduce risk of gastro-intestinal tract bleed) and replace clotting factors using fresh frozen plasma (FFP), cryoprecipitate (factor VIII and fibrinogen) and platelets as needed. Prophylactic heparin is also needed as the increased coagulation increase the septic patient’s risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).

 

Summary

Sepsis causes a multitude of complex changes at cellular, humoral and macrophysiological levels. The changes are largely mediated by the immune system with its complex interrelationship of white blood cells, complement system and antibodies, bringing about the relaease of an array of inflammatory mediators. Apart from neutralising the infection, these mediators act in a disordered way in severe sepsis to cause capillary leakage, organ dysfunction and shock. There are also changes in the way coagulation and fibrinolysis are mediated, potentially resulting in disseminated intravascular coagulation.

document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,PRESCRIBING,CBRN,CHEMICAL,BIOLOGICAL,PATIENT GROUP DIRECTIONS (PGDS),CONTINGENCY]]>
document.body:
Patient Group Directions (PGDs) for the chemical and biological countermeasures are available on this section of the Department of Health website. Patient Group Directions (PGDs) are documents which make it legal for medicines to be given to groups of patients - for example in a mass casualty situation - without individual prescriptions having to be written for each patient. They can also be used to empower staff other than doctors (for example paramedics and nurses) to legally give the medicine in question.

Access: Available to the general public.

document.description: A letter highlighting the launch of Project Argus – Health: a multimedia presentation which explores the possible consequences for the health sector in the aftermath of a terrorist attack and the risks it itself may face.
document.body:
This is a letter from Richard Hampton, Head of NHS Security Management Service; Chris Phillips Head of the National Counter Terrorism Security Office and Andy Cobb, CONTEST and CNI Lead, Emergency Preparedness Division, Department of Health.

It highlights the launch of Project Argus – Health: a multimedia presentation which explores the possible consequences for the health sector in the aftermath of a terrorist attack and the risks it itself may face.

The simulation will allow those responsible for responding to such an incident to think through the possible risks to their staff, patients and estate and plan to mitigate against possible impacts. It also considers in detail how effective security arrangements can aid the prevention, handling and recovery from this and other similar incidents.

Whilst the focus of Project Argus – Health is on security, the learning outcomes can be used by the likes of Estates and Facilities, Emergency Planning Officers, Risk Managers and Clinicians, in support of their wider roles and responsibilities around resilience and business continuity management.

Publication history information: Published 9th December 2009.

Access: Available to the general public.
