document.title: Pulmonary embolism
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - emergency and urgent care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ RESPIRATORY,EMERGENCY CARE,CLINICAL LIBRARY,PULMONARY EMBOLISM]]>
document.description: Part of the National Knowledge Week for Foundation Doctors 2007. Reviewed May 2009.
document.body:
111-1Pulmonary embolism

Written by Dr Stewart McMorran, July 2007.
Reviewed by Dr Stewart McMorran, May 2009.

PDF version of this topic

Back to Knowledge Week contents

 

Key Learning Points 

  1. Consider a diagnosis of Pulmonary Embolism (PE) in any patient presenting with unexplained breathlessness, pleuritic chest pain or haemoptysis.

  2. Assess and document clinical probability in all patients with a possible PE.

  3. Major risk factors include recent abdominal or pelvic surgery, reduced mobility and during the last trimester of pregnancy.

  4. A negative D-dimer is useful for ruling out PE in patients with a low or intermediate probability of PE.

  5. D-dimer should not be requested in patients with a high probability of PE.

  6. CTPA is the recommended initial lung imaging modality to diagnose PE.

  7. ECG, CXR, and ABGs are essential base line investigations in the diagnosis of PE.

  8. Commence treatment with heparin whilst awaiting imaging in patients with an intermediate or high probability of PE.

  9. Consider thrombolysis in patients with massive PE and cardiovascular collapse.

  10. Consider thigh length graduated compression stockings and low molecular weight heparin in hospital patients at increased risk of venous thromboembolism.

 

More Detailed information

Pulmonary embolism continues to be a major source of morbidity and mortality. National guidelines were developed by the British Thoracic Society in 1997 and updated in 2003. They have been widely adopted and modified locally.

Pulmonary embolism should be suspected in any patient presenting with breathlessness, pleuritic chest pain or haemoptysis especially where no alternative diagnosis is forthcoming. Wherever possible, a careful history should be taken looking for factors placing patients at increased risk for venous thromboembolism. These may be categorised as major risk factors, relative risk from 5-20, for example, lower limb fracture; or minor, relative risk 2-4, for example, oral contraceptive pill. The presence of risk factors, clinical presentation, and absence or not of an alternative diagnosis, can be combined to conclude a low, intermediate or high probability of PE. Patients with low or intermediate PE require further investigation, particularly d-dimers, to decide whether to proceed to radiological imaging. Patients with high probability of PE should proceed immediately to radiological imaging without the need for d-dimers. CTPA is the imaging modality of choice. In the absence of ready access to CTPA, then an isotope lung scan may be used to exclude PE provided that a chest radiograph is normal. For patients presenting clinically with massive PE and cardiovascular collapse, CTPA or echocardiography should be used to confirm diagnosis.

Treatment should be commenced as soon as possible. For patients with intermediate or high clinical probability of PE, this may precede imaging. For those with low probability, it may be delayed until the diagnosis has been confirmed. Low molecular weight heparin is the treatment of choice. For patients with clinically massive PE, the first line treatment is thrombolysis. Oral anticoagulation can follow once PE has been reliably confirmed.

 


 

Links to important sources of further information

document.title: Raising medical professionals' awareness of carbon monoxide poisoning
document.publisher: All Party Parliamentary Gas Safety Group (APPGSG)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,CLINICAL LIBRARY,POISONING,ALL OTHER]]>
document.body:
The All Party Parliamentary Gas Safety Group (APPGSG) is increasingly concerned that little is being done to ensure that medical professionals are able to correctly diagnose the symptoms of carbon monoxide, and treat victims effectively. For this reason, in April 2008 they decided to undertake an inquiry into this issue to determine the extent of the problem, and make recommendations on how to improve diagnosis rates.

After a public meeting in the Houses of Parliament they called for evidence into medical professionals’ awareness of carbon monoxide poisoning and received a number of responses from interested parties and members of the public who have been misdiagnosed. This evidence forms the basis of the All Party Parliamentary Gas Safety Group’s report into carbon monoxide awareness among medical professionals.

Access: Available to the general public

document.title: Recent developments in emergency planning
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,HEALTH MANAGEMENT,MAJOR INCIDENT,RISK MANAGEMENT,POLICY,QUALITY AND MONITORING,CONTINGENCY]]>
document.body:
111-1Recent developments in emergency planning

Written by A Bleetman, joint editor of the Contingency section, 2006. Last reviewed and updated March 2009.

The implementation of the Civil Contingencies Act (CCA) in 2004 has led to the development and implementation of enhanced planning and assessment in the health service.

The Department of Health released new Emergency Planning Guidance in October 2005. This provides a framework for the NHS emergency preparedness and ensures consistency and collaboration within the NHS and with external organisations. The Audit Commission has established standards and guidelines for effective assessment of Category 1 responders.

The CCA, and the DH guidance, emphasise the importance of business continuity management and recovery planning in all plans.
The DH guidance recommends that each trust appoint an Emergency Planning Officer, that emergency planning is the responsibility of the Chief Executive and directors and that collaboration with external organisations is established. All staff must be aware of the emergency plans through training and regular testing (table top exercises and mock incidents). It is not enough that an organisation has a plan, it must be shared with staff and regularly exercised so that all staff are competent and aware of their roles. There is now clear advice on the type and frequency of testing of plans and exercising that planners have to fulfil within their organisations.
The UK resilience website contains useful content to support emergency planning and preparedness, including tools for self assessment. Emergency planners in the health service are now required to extend their efforts to planning for pandemic influenza and to consider business continuity management.

Technological developments include the design and implementation of computerised call-in systems, intranet sites for plans and on-line training.

]]>

document.title: Severe sepsis care bundles
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - emergency and urgent care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,CLINICAL LIBRARY,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,SEPSIS,SURGERY,PERIOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT,COMPLICATIONS,SEPSIS,CRITICAL CARE,CLINICAL TOPICS,SEPSIS & INFLAMMATORY RESPONSE]]>
document.description: Part of the National Knowledge Week for Sepsis Bundles, updated in October 2009.
document.body:
111-1Severe sepsis care bundles

Written by Dr Ron Daniels, September 2007.
Updated by Dr Ron Daniels, October 2009.

Back to Knowledge Week contents

 


The Surviving Sepsis Campaign represents an international collaboration of healthcare experts, including representatives from the European Society of Intensive Care Medicine (ESICM), Society of Critical Care Medicine (SCCM) and International Sepsis Forum (ISF). The campaign is committed to the reduction of the mortality from severe sepsis worldwide by 25%. Phase III of the Campaign encourages the use of global plan-do-study-act (PDSA) cycles to increase levels of compliance with the guidelines, and to measure improvements.

In March 2004, recommendations drawn from research, clinical trials and expert opinion were collated and published as the ‘Surviving Sepsis Campaign guidelines for the management of severe sepsis and septic shock’ 1. These were subsequently revised in 20082. A major change was the introduction of the GRADE3 system of evidencing recommendations, such that the Campaign are now able to recommend at Grade 1 (‘you should...’) or Grade 2 (you probably should...’).
 
The Institute for Healthcare Improvement (U.S.), in collaboration with the Surviving Sepsis Campaign, developed two ‘bundles’, or packages of care, for the treatment of those with severe sepsis:

The Severe Sepsis Resuscitation Bundle to complete in 6 hours following the recognition of severe sepsis 

The Severe Sepsis Management Bundle to complete in 24 hours

Healthcare professionals and organisations are encouraged to deliver each aspect of each of these bundles. Each component of each bundle is deliverable, measurable, evidence-based (to a greater or lesser degree) and not currently reliably performed. The Campaign has undertaken to monitor delivery of these care bundles across those institutions providing data, and to link delivery (‘compliance’) to outcome for patients.


What is a care bundle?

Essentially, a care bundle is a package of care. A typical care bundle will have between 4 and 8 elements of care. From a research point of view, the beauty of a care bundle is that it is easily measurable: a patient will either satisfy the whole care bundle or they will not.

For a care bundle to be effective, it must satisfy the following criteria4:

  • Each element must be based on sound evidence
  • The delivery of each element must be in need of improvement
  • To deliver each element must be achievable in terms of resources
  • No element should be a major source of controversy
  • The bundle as a whole must do more good than harm
  • The delivery of each element must be measurable

In other words, a care bundle comprises a group of interventions which have been shown to improve outcome, which are achievable, measurable and not yet performed in the majority of patients. The principle is that the benefit to a patient of the whole care bundle is greater than the sum of the parts.

 

The Surviving Sepsis Campaign Resuscitation Bundle

In its raw form, the Resuscitation Bundle is summarised below (items in bold are level 1 recommendations, items not in bold level 2):

The Bundle is designed to be completed within 6 hours following the onset of severe sepsis. This will require close cooperation between the teams identifying sepsis- for example, in the Emergency Department- and those with the skills necessary to place and manage central venous catheters, arterial cannulae, and infusions of vasoactive drugs. In practice in the United Kingdom, this latter team will normally be Critical Care although some Emergency Departments have started to equip themselves with these skills5.

 

Elements of the Resuscitation Bundle

Serum lactate measured

Lactate, or lactic acid, is the product of anaerobic metabolism of glucose by the tissues. This process is less efficient than aerobic metabolism in terms of ATP production per unit of substrate, and occurs when insufficient oxygen is delivered to the tissues.

There is good evidence that lactate carries prognostic value. One study demonstrated the ability to risk stratify patients according to their serum lactate at presentation6. Patients with a lactate measurement in excess of 4 mmol/l had a mortality of around 40%, compared with under 15% for patients with a lactate of <2 mmol/l. Lactate is particularly useful measured serially, to guide response to resuscitation and fluid therapy.

It should be noted that lactate is not specific to organ hypoperfusion secondary to severe sepsis. Indeed, some units prefer serum procalcitonin as a more specific marker7. It is perfectly acceptable to use a surrogate marker of tissue hypoperfusion in achieving the Resuscitation Bundle.


Blood cultures obtained prior to antibiotic administration

Two or more blood cultures are recommended, one drawn percutaneously and one through each vascular access device if it has been in for longer than 48 hours. The rationale behind this is that, if the culture from the access device is positive earlier than that for the percutaneous sample, the device may well be the source of infection 8. Similarly, if the same organism is isolated from more than one culture, the chance that this is the organism responsible for the sepsis is elevated9.

At this point it is also recommended that consideration should be given to sampling of other biofluids- cerebrospinal fluid, sputum, urine, synovial fluid, pleural fluid etc- where clinical signs point to a source of infection.
 

Antibiotic administration

The SSC Bundle stipulates that antibiotics should be given within 1 hour.

There is ample evidence to support early and appropriate antibiotic administration, such that it can be argued that this is one of the most important aspects of either Care Bundle. One prospective cohort study of patients admitted with bacteraemia demonstrated a reduction in mortality from 60% to around 25% associated with appropriate initial antibiotic therapy10. More recently, a large retrospective study showed that, in patients with septic shock, to delay administration of antibiotic was associated with an increase in mortality of 7.6% for each hour’s delay11.

Antibiotics should be administered according to local pathogen profiles, taking into account knowledge of local resistance patterns and organisms. One or more broad spectrum antibiotic should be administered in the first instance, with review and probable change to a narrower spectrum once the causative organism has been isolated.
 

Fluid challenges

Fluids should be administered intravenously in volumes of 500-1000 ml if crystalloids are used, and 300-500 ml if colloids are used. There is little evidence to support the use of colloids over crystalloids12,13. Colloids have a smaller volume of distribution than crystalloids, and thus less volume is required to achieve the same degree of intravascular volume expansion.

Patients with severe sepsis frequently require large volumes of fluids for adequate resuscitation, and are likely to have ongoing requirements far in excess of usual maintenance fluids for at least the first 24 hours. Input will almost always exceed output within this early phase, and fluid balance is a poor estimate of fluid requirement at this stage. It is appropriate to give large volumes of fluid, particularly in the presence of shock, provided the patient is monitored closely and frequently reassessed for signs of fluid overload and pulmonary oedema.

In hypoperfused patients, a minimum volume of 20ml/kg is recommended as an initial bolus. Patients with shock will frequently require volumes of up to 60ml/kg in resuscitation- for an average adult male, this represents nearly 5 litres of intravenous fluid.


Early Goal-Directed Therapy

The remainder of the Resuscitation Bundle falls under the umbrella of Early Goal-Directed Therapy (EGDT). The concept of goal-directed therapy in anaesthesia and Critical Care is not new14. Essentially, the term refers to the manipulation of physiology through intervention to achieve pre-determined goals.

EGDT as discussed here relates to a paper by Rivers et al15, in which 263 patients presenting to an Emergency Department with severe sepsis or septic shock were randomly assigned to receive either EGDT or standard therapy during the first 6 hours of their care. In hospital mortality for the EGDT group was 30.5%, as compared with 46.5% for the control group (p=0.009).

Previous researchers have explored this approach with treatment being started on the intensive care unit after the development of organ failure. The aim of Rivers’ approach was uniquely different because he initiated resuscitation and treatment early, before the onset of organ failure. He realised that sepsis, like myocardial infarction and stroke, is a time-sensitive disease, and that early intervention may help prevent a catastrophic and irreversible decline. This is logical, because the rationale behind resuscitating a patient is to prevent further organ dysfunction and failure. If resuscitation is delayed until after cell dysfunction and death are present, then strategies like these designed to provide the cells with more oxygen will not work.

Oxygen supply and delivery

In septic shock the abnormalities in the circulation: intravascular volume depletion; peripheral vasodilatation, capillary shunting, oedema, impaired mitochondrial oxygen transport and myocardial depression- along with the increased metabolism, lead to an imbalance between the delivery of oxygen to the tissues and oxygen demand. Put another way, the tissues require more oxygen than they can receive. This leads to global tissue hypoxia, cell dysfunction and cell death; eventually leading to multiple organ failure. The resuscitation strategy looks to restore the balance between oxygen supply and demand.

Oxygen supply (also known as oxygen delivery, DO2) is the amount of oxygen delivered to the whole body from the lungs. It is the product of the total blood flow or cardiac output (CO) and the oxygen content of the arterial blood (CaO2):

DO2 = CO x CaO2

The oxygen content of arterial blood (CaO2) is in turn described by the equation:

CaO2 = (K1 x Hb x SaO2) + (K2 x PaO2)

Where Hb is the haemoglobin concentration (g/litre), SaO2 is the arterial oxygen saturation and PaO2 is the arterial oxygen partial pressure.  K1 and K2 are constants- that is, numbers which do not change between patients.

K1 x Hb x SaO2 tells us how much oxygen, in ml, is carried by the haemoglobin in the red cells. This is by far the majority of the oxygen content. 

K2 x PaO2 represents the oxygen dissolved in plasma. In practice, even at high FiO2, this oxygen is insignificant.

Therefore, the oxygen content of arterial blood (CaO2) can be approximated to:

CaO2 = K1 x Hb x SaO2

The oxygen combining capacity of Hb is represented by the constant K1 (Hufner number). The exact value is controversial but is generally taken as 1.31, which means that each gram of Hb binds 1.31 ml of oxygen. K1 is a constant (we can’t change it), so for the purposes of what we can do to affect the oxygen delivery can be omitted:

CaO2 = Hb x SaO2

Summarising the above, oxygen delivery can be thought of as :

DO2 = CO x Hb x SaO2

The resuscitation strategy in the Rivers study enhances oxygen delivery (DO2) to the tissues by optimising cardiac output (CO). This is achieved by improving cardiac preload, afterload and contractility.


The first goal:  CVP > 8mmHg

Patients with sepsis that continue to be hypotensive (or have a high lactate in excess of 4 mmol/l) despite an initial bolus of 20 ml/kg crystalloid have septic shock. They should have a central venous catheter (‘central line’) inserted. Their central venous pressure (CVP) should be measured and resuscitation should be commenced with fluid boluses of 500-1500ml every 30 minutes to achieve and maintain a CVP greater than 8 mmHg. Fluid boluses should be repeated as required. This can be thought of as the first goal or first resuscitation end point.

Giving fluids increases cardiac preload (the amount of blood returning to the heart) and improves cardiac output. This can be explained by the Frank-Starling Law: essentially that the heart muscle contracts more strongly when it is under some degree of stretch. The improvement in cardiac output will improve oxygen delivery, as previously discussed.

Central venous catheters must be placed under strict aseptic technique and by personnel with appropriate training and skills. This may be a doctor or nurse practitioner in any acute speciality.


The second goal:  MAP > 65mmHg or systolic > 90mmHg

If the CVP is greater than 8 mmHg (the patient is adequately ‘filled’); but the MAP (mean arterial blood pressure) is less than 65 mmHg or systolic less than 90mmHg, the patient has septic shock. A vasopressor (a drug to constrict the blood vessels, mainly arterioles) infusion of noradrenaline should be started to maintain a MAP of at least 65 mmHg in these circumstances. The aim of this intervention, in the presence of adequate intravascular resuscitation, is to ensure adequate perfusion (blood supply) to the organs.

This can be thought of as the second goal or second resuscitation end point, aiming to keep the MAP at above 65 mmHg.

Vasopressor and inotropic infusions must only be initiated and supervised by personnel with appropriate training and skills. This will usually be doctors or senior nurses from Critical Care or Coronary Care and Acute or Emergency Medicine.


The third goal : ScvO2 > 70%

Central venous oxygen saturation (ScvO2)  is measured by taking blood in a heparinised syringe (a normal blood gas syringe is fine) from the central venous line and measuring the oxygen saturation using the blood gas analyser. The result will be the oxygen saturation of central venous blood or ScvO2. It can be considered as a surrogate for measuring the balance between oxygen delivery and demand. If low (< 70%), the tissues are extracting too much oxygen from each ml of blood that passes. This may be due to a very high oxygen demand or too low an oxygen delivery.

Rivers used a central line capable of continuously measuring ScvO2. It is possible to achieve an adequate level of monitoring by using intermittent sampling from the central line, hourly to begin with, and measuring the ScvO2 using the blood gas analyser.

If the ScvO2 is low (in practice this situation is not the norm even in septic shock) then interventions which may help include increasing the oxygen content of the blood and increasing cardiac output. Both will increase oxygen delivery. Oxygen content may be improved through the administration of high-flow oxygen or consideration to the provision of ventilation. Additionally, if the patient is anaemic, transfusion may improve oxygen carrying capacity.

The first recommendation in the event of a low ScvO2 is thus to transfuse the patient to achieve a haematocrit of >30% (approximating to a haemoglobin concentration of > 10g/dl).

If the patient is not anaemic, or if a repeat ScvO2 after transfusion remains low, the next strategy to redress the imbalance between oxygen delivery and demand is to increase the cardiac output to improve oxygen delivery. To enhance cardiac output, an inotropic infusion of dobutamine is started.

A dobutamine infusion is started at 2.5 mcg/kg/min and increased by 2.5 mcg/kg/min every 30 minutes until the ScvO2 is greater than 70%, or until the maximum dose of 20mcg/kg/min is reached.

Vasopressor and inotropic infusions must only be initiated and supervised by personnel with appropriate training and skills. In practice this will be doctors or senior nurses from Critical Care or Coronary Care.

Mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2) measured from a pulmonary artery catheter is the measurement which would most accurately reflect the imbalance between oxygen supply and demand. However, it has been shown and is widely accepted that central venous oxygen saturation (ScvO2) measured from a central venous catheter gives a good approximation16. For this reason it is perfectly acceptable to use central venous oxygen saturation measurements.

It is impossible to determine from the Rivers study which particular facet of the protocol was the most beneficial and responsible for the reduction in mortality; so the protocol as a whole must be recommended. Rivers himself pointed out that Early Goal Directed Therapy is not an emergency department study, but a study that provides best care to the patients with sepsis, as early as possible. Other studies have been published that support the beneficial effects of the Rivers study and have shown that Early Goal Directed Therapy (EGDT) can be achieved in clinical practice without the use of dedicated study teams17.

That a part of the EGDT component of the Resuscitation Bundle is recommended at level 1 and a part at level 2 is not strictly scientifically sound- the recommendations are all based on the same study. It does reflect concern around the possibly contribution of the ScvO2 target to Rivers’ original study, and discomfort (concerns exacerbated by the Canadian TRICC study18) in many countries around striving to achieve a target haemoglobin concentration in excess of 10g/dl.


The Surviving Sepsis Campaign Management Bundle

The Management Bundle consists of a set of 4 tasks to be completed within 24 hours of the onset of severe sepsis. It largely relates to Critical Care. It should not, however, be viewed as following on from the Resuscitation Bundle, efforts should be made to implement it concurrently.
 

The Management Bundle can be viewed as three components for consideration and one component to do! It is, therefore, encumbent on individual units to determine and set policies on the use of low-dose steroids, activated Protein C and glycaemic control.


Low-dose steroids

There is some evidence that steroids administered at physiological dosage (for example, hydrocortisone 50mg qds) to patients with shock resistant to fluid resuscitation, and requiring the administration of vasopressors, are of benefit 19,20,21. The study by Annane et al demonstrated shock reversal and reduced mortality in patients with shock resistant to vasopressors. The two smaller studies showed a reversal in septic shock in patients with shock requiring vasopressors. These results appeared to be supported by a Cochrane meta-analysis of 15 randomised controlled trials22.

The European CORTICUS study, published in 200823, did not support these conclusions. This large, multi-centre, placebo-controlled randomised controlled trial of 499 patients did not show a mortality benefit in the group receiving treatment, although they did appear to have a more rapid resolution of shock. Due to the potentially deleterious pro-infective properties of these agents and a tendency to exacerbate myopathy common in Critical Care patients, this trial prompted the downgrading of this recommendation to level 2.

The guidelines stipulate that steroids be considered in patients with shock unresponsive to fluids and vasopressors according to local policy. ACTH stimulation testing does not appear to predict steroid-responsiveness and is not recommended.
 

Activated Protein C

Recombinant Activated Protein C, or Drotrecogin alpha (trade name Xigris™, Eli Lilly & Co.) is recommended for use in patients with severe sepsis at particularly high risk of death. A number of means to assess this risk have been used, including the presence of the failure of two or more organs, refractory shock, and an APACHE II score (a physiological scoring system used in Critical Care: Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation) of >25. This latter criterion arose from data from the recombinant human Protein C Worldwide Evaluation in Severe Sepsis (PROWESS) study24. This large randomised controlled trial demonstrated a significant reduction in mortality (6.1% absolute reduction) in patients with an APACHE II score of >25.
A second RCT, the ADDRESS study25, investigated patients with a lower risk of death measured by APACHE II scores of <25. This study found no benefit in this group of patients and recommended that drotrecogin alpha not be used in patients with single organ failure or a lower score.

However, severe sepsis and response to Protein C are time-sensitive. It would be illogical to wait and watch a patient deteriorate to an arbitrary defined physiology score before commencing potentially life-saving treatment. The SSC guidelines recommend that organisations create and follow local policies. Most Critical Care Networks in the United Kingdom have policies focusing on the presence of failure of two or more organs, or of septic shock, rather than the APACHE score. This approach is supported by NICE, which recommends the use of activated Protein C in adults with severe sepsis already receiving maximum support and with 2 or more organ failures26.

The coagulation cascade and inflammatory pathways play key roles in the development of multiple organ failure due to severe sepsis. Drotrecogin alpha (activated) has anti-inflammatory and antithrombotic properties and promotes fibrinolysis, which helps to explain its benefit in these patients, and also its known side-effect of bleeding occurring during infusion.

Not every organisation uses activated Protein C. It is a costly drug (c. £5000 per patient), and sceptics cite variously the risk of bleeding, the ADDRESS study27 (though these were designed to evaluate efficacy and safety in different patient groups), and perceived influence of the company manufacturing the agent over the guidelines. A Cochrane review from 200728 examined a priori all randomised controlled trials in the use of activated Protein C. Being scientifically rigorously designed, the analysis of 4 such trials included only one trial in the target patient population and found the pooled data to show no outcome benefit- however the clinical implications of this study are unclear.

Against these arguments, in addition to anecdotal advocacy, is an observational dataset held by the Intensive Care National Audit and Research Centre (ICNARC, UK) which would appear to support significant benefits in patients with two or more organ failure29. Results from the forthcoming PROWESS-Shock30 study will hopefully provide more clarification.


Tight glycaemic control

The initial recommendation to control blood glucose arose from work by van den Berghe et al31, in which Intensive Care patients randomised to receive tight glycaemic control by insulin infusion (blood glucose between 80 and 110mg/dl) showed a statistically significant mortality reduction from 8% to 4.6%. This was, however, in a closed, predominantly cardiac surgical, unit. On repeating the trial in a medical patient population, the same investigators found no outcome benefit in terms of mortality32.

More recently, the NICE-SUGAR study33- a randomised controlled trial in 6,000 patients of intensive insulin therapy (target glucose < 6.0mmol/l) against ‘conventional’ insulin therapy (insulin commenced in the event of glucose exceeding 10mmol/l)- showed an increase in mortality and in adverse events in the intervention group. The multi-centre German VISEP study34 showed no benefit in mortality using similar treatment triggers- an increased rate of severe hypoglycaemia led to this trial being stopped early. Preliminary results from these studies led to the 2008 guidelines revision being far more pragmatic with relation to this component- organisations are simply encouraged to take steps to control hyperglycaemia according to local guidelines.


Protective ventilation

It has been known for some time that ventilator-associated lung injury (VALI), a sterile inflammatory process which can lead to fibroproliferation and permanent damage, is exacerbated by barotrauma (excessive airway pressures) and cyclical volutrauma (cycling from large to small lung volumes).

The ARDSnet mechanical ventilation study35 demonstrated that tidal volumes during mechanical ventilation of 6ml per kg body weight were associated with better outcomes than tidal volumes of 12ml/kg. Other studies36,37 have shown benefits in limiting plateau airway pressures. The recommendation within the Management Bundle is to limit plateau airway pressures to <30cmH20.

In practice with modern ventilators this is relatively straightforward to achieve in many patients. Patients with more severe lung injury, or with progression to Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS), may present more of a challenge. Strategies such as permissive hypercapnia (allowing the carbon dioxide blood tension to rise to supranormal levels through sacrificing minute ventilation for lung protection) may be of assistance,as may techniques such as prone ventilation and high frequency oscillator ventilation (HFOV).

 

Challenges in achieving the Care Bundles

Never before have changes in clinical care pathways for a diverse population been intended to apply across entire hospitals globally. Challenges in achieving these goals remain- challenges not only in practical aspects and resource availability, but also in knowledge and acceptance.
 

Academic debate

Academic debate is clearly healthy and essential, in order to produce the right guidelines, to ensure that they remain current, and to implement them in the right way. Debate has surrounded many aspects of the SSC recommendations and Bundles. Some of the criticisms addressed to the studies underpinning the recommendations have been presented above.

A care bundle aims to achieve maximum impact by taking a list of recommendations and selecting those which are deliverable, measurable, supported by strong evidence of improving outcomes, and which are currently not performed well. It is inevitable that this process will not satisfy all. An individual may prefer to see other elements of the initial recommendations in the Bundles- for example, DVT prophylaxis replacing steroid administration. Some have criticised the lack of inclusion of selective digestive decontamination.

It should be remembered that the Bundles are neither complete packages of care nor exclusive- those patients achieving the bundles are likely to do so as a measure of a generally high standard of care. The evidence behind each element is as strong as the current evidence base allows, and the guidelines are to be reviewed regularly in order to maintain currency.  In time, with sufficient data, this may allow the international Critical Care community to determine which elements are responsible for any identified improvements. In other words, the application of the Bundles across many countries simultaneously will permit a global evaluation of the recommendations, allowing the field of sepsis care to progress at a rate which would otherwise have been impossible.


Industry

There has been fierce criticism of the funding of the Surviving Sepsis Campaign by industry38.  It is beyond the scope of this project to examine this in detail. Suffice it to say that, without industry funding, the Campaign would not have achieved the progress made to date- the message simply would not have got to the wider healthcare community without funding.


‘Operationalising’ the Resuscitation Bundle

It is easier for an organisation to implement the Management than the Resuscitation Bundle- there is an extra 18 hours available in which to complete it, and the patients are in the controllable and highly resourced environment of Critical Care. Across the United Kingdom, around three times as many patients receive the Management Bundle as the Resuscitation Bundle.

In the U.K, major challenges lie in placing central venous catheters, starting vasoactive infusions, and measuring ScvO2 outside Critical Care. This has led a number of clinicians worldwide to abandon the SSC Bundle and create a ‘simpler’ bundle, often targeting the first hour after presentation. This detracts from the advantages of uniform implementation of a credible guideline on a global scale described above.

Perhaps a better way to approach the problem is to look at local resources available, and ways in which they can be moulded to achieve the desired change. An example is the availability of Critical Care Outreach teams, who have the skills and experience to assist with the provision of Early Goal-Directed Therapy.

Our programme of education in sepsis care exploits this resource in order to maximise compliance with the Bundles. Survive SEPSIS (www.survivesepsis.org) is approved by the Surviving Sepsis Campaign nationally and internationally. The programme introduces the concept of the Sepsis Six39- six tasks to be completed by non-specialist staff within the first hour- and the need for close and early liaison with Critical Care to complete Early Goal-Directed Therapy. We have, in as yet unpublished data from over 500 patients, demonstrated that the Sepsis Six itself is independently predictive of good outcome.

document.title: SITREP reporting and operational problems
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,CLINICAL LIBRARY,ORGANISATIONAL AND OTHER ISSUES,RECORD KEEPING]]>
document.description: Letter to strategic health authority chief executives on the importance of appropriate and timely SITREP reporting.
document.body:
This letter from David Flory (Director General, NHS Finance, Performance and Operations) and Ian Dalton (National Director, NHS Flu Resilience) to strategic health authority chief executives on the importance of appropriate and timely SITREP reporting aims to:

  • "reiterate the importance of appropriate and timely SITREP reporting and to reinforce expectations around established guidance for trusts reporting ambulance handover delays"
  • "to ask strategic health authority chief executives  to ensure that SHAs quality assure/validate trust daily SITREP data before submitting to DH"

The letter explains that "this winter (2009/10) the expectation is again of a whole system approach to managing winter and pandemic flu and other pressures across each regional health economy and across the NHS and social care generally. Early daily SITREPs highlight ambulance delays and potentially indicating significant pressure on the service in some parts of the country".
 

Access: Available to the general public. Portable Document File / PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader.

document.body: <![CDATA[ The National Stroke Strategy, covering stroke services in England, was launched in December 2007.  It was inclusive in its development and was welcomed warmly by all stakeholders.  The Strategy recognised that staff working in stroke had variable levels of knowledge and skills and that there was no nationally recognised stroke specific training.  DH liaised with professional organisations, the NHS Workforce Review Team and the Stroke Association to establish a UK Forum for Stroke Training to provide nationally recognised, quality assured and transferable education and learning programmes in stroke at pre-registration and post graduate level.  The forum set up a steering group with wide ranging representation and from all UK countries. Task Groups produced reports which were brought together into this Stroke-specific education framework.]]>

document.body:
Conclusion: More formal economic evaluation would allow better use of the available data. All identified studies were conducted in unconscious patients. However, further research is needed to evaluate new ODM probes that may be tolerated by awake patients. Given the paucity of the existing economic evidence base, any further primary research should include an economic evaluation or should provide data suitable for use in an economic model.

Method: This review was based on a systematic review conducted by the US AHRQ, supplemented by evidence from any additional studies identified. Data were extracted on mortality, length of stay overall and in critical care, complications and quality of life. The economic assessment evaluated strategies involving ODM compared with standard care, PACs, pulse contour analysis monitoring and lithium or thermodilution cardiac monitoring.

Results: The results show that ODM strategies are likely to be cost-effective. Please see full report for details of results.

document.title: The harmful health effects of recreational ecstasy : a systematic review of observational evidence
document.publisher: NIHR Evaluation, Trials and Studies Coordinating Centre (NETSCC)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,CLINICAL LIBRARY,POISONING,ALL OTHER]]>
document.body:
Conclusion: Recreational use of ecstasy is associated with significant deficits in neurocognitive function (particularly immediate and delayed verbal memory) and increased psychopathological symptoms. Ecstasy is associated with a range of acute harms but appears to be a rare cause of death in isolation.

Method: Studies were categorised according to design, with systematic research syntheses (Level I evidence) the most valid and least open to bias. Where Level I evidence was not available, controlled observational studies (Level II evidence) were systematically reviewed. If neither Level I nor Level II evidence was available, uncontrolled case series and case reports (Level III evidence) were systematically surveyed. Data were extracted by one reviewer and a sample checked by a second.

Results: Small but significant deficits for ecstasy users compared to controls were reported in areas relating to attention, memory, psychomotor speed, executive systems functioning, and self-reported depressive symptoms. Two major syndromes are most commonly reported as the immediate cause of death in fatal cases: hyperthermia and hyponatraemia.

Citation: Rogers G, Elston J, Garside R, Roome C, Taylor R, Younger P, et al. The harmful health effects of recreational ecstasy: a systematic review of observational evidence. Health Technology Assessment 2009; 13(6):1-338.

Publication History: Published February 2009.

Access: Available to the general public.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Emergency Care]]>
document.title: The surviving sepsis campaign
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - emergency and urgent care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,CLINICAL LIBRARY,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,SEPSIS,SURGERY,PERIOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT,COMPLICATIONS,SEPSIS,CRITICAL CARE,CLINICAL TOPICS,SEPSIS & INFLAMMATORY RESPONSE]]>
document.description: Part of the National Knowledge Week for Sepsis Bundles, updated in October 2009.
document.body:
111-1The surviving sepsis campaign

Written by Dr Ron Daniels, September 2007.
Updated by Dr Ron Daniels, October 2009.

Back to Knowledge Week contents

 

The Surviving Sepsis Campaign (SSC) was developed as a collaboration of the European Society of Critical Care Medicine, the International Sepsis Forum and the Society of Critical Care Medicine. The initial aim was to help meet the challenges of sepsis and to improve its management, diagnosis, and treatment. 13 additional international professional bodies provided additional contribution. The agreement between the three founding organizations and funding for the campaign was concluded December 31, 2008. In a number of countries, including the U.K, national steering groups remain to continue striving to implement the Bundles reliably. In the U.S, assistance in implementing the bundles can be obtained through the Society of Critical Care Medicine's Paragon program. The Surviving Sepsis Campaign website and the SSC database will remain available until the end of 2011.

The following outlines the history and development of the Campaign.

Phase I

In 2002, at the 15th Annual Conference of the European Society of Intensive Care Medicine, Critical Care experts from around the world agreed that concerted action was required across the world to reduce the mortality from severe sepsis. A desire to reduce the number of deaths from sepsis by 25% (equating to a relative risk reduction or RRR) over a 5 year period became known as the Barcelona Declaration1.

The Declaration was supported by a 5-point action plan, which subsequently evolved to the following 6 point plan.

  • Awareness: increase awareness of healthcare professionals, governments, health and funding agencies, and the public of the high frequency and mortality of sepsis
  • Diagnosis: improve the early and accurate diagnosis of sepsis by developing a clear and clinically relevant definition of sepsis and disseminating it to our peers
  • Treatment: increase the use of appropriate treatments and interventions by disseminating the range of care options and urging their timely use
  • Education: encourage the education of all healthcare professionals who manage sepsis patients by providing leadership, support and information to them about all aspects of sepsis management, including diagnosis, treatments and interventions, and standards of care
  • Counselling: provide a framework for improving and accelerating access to post-ICU care and counselling for sepsis patients
  • Referral: recognise the need for clear referral guidelines that are accepted and adopted at a local level in all countries by initiating the development of global guidelines

Significant challenges lay, and still remain, in achieving these goals. One of the most significant and persistent lies in inconsistencies in diagnosing and recognising sepsis. Many physicians do not use, or are not aware of, the current definition of sepsis despite attempts to standardise terminology and diagnostic criteria. Indeed, in one study only 17% of clinicians agreed on a definition of sepsis 2, and this disparity results in missed diagnosis and delayed treatment.  Part of the reason for this is that clinicians are used to a single test, or a collection of a small number of signs and tests, to identify a condition- for example, Troponin T elevation with a convincing history or ECG changes to diagnose acute myocardial infarction.

The diagnosis of severe sepsis is currently complex, requiring a suspicion of infection, the presence of 2 or more criteria for the Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) and evidence of organ dysfunction, tissue hyporperfusion or shock. Groups are exploring biochemical and hormonal markers in an attempt to identify a more reliable sepsis ‘ECG’. Others, including a large study sponsored by the European Society of Intensive Care Medicine, are exploring genetic components3. To collate all of the information necessary to make the diagnosis, therefore, has historically involved a number of healthcare professionals over the course of many hours. A challenge now lies in education to raise awareness to assimilate this information rapidly and to make the diagnosis early so that appropriate treatment can be initiated. Information technology, where available, can provide electronic recognition and protocolised pathways.

Analogies have been drawn between the challenges now facing professionals caring for patients with severe sepsis and the improvements made in the treatment of acute myocardial infarction since the 1960s. At this time, the mortality of patients suffering an in-hospital myocardial infarction was around 30%4. Studies suggest that current in-hospital mortality at 30 days is much lower, at around 5%5,6,7.
 These improvements have been realised through the step-wise implementation of interventions shown to add benefit. Each alone may have provided small but significant benefits, but over a 40 year timeframe the added benefit has led to a relative risk reduction of an astonishing 83%.


Phase II

The Surviving Sepsis Campaign Guidelines

In March 2004, two years following the Barcelona Declaration, recommendations drawn from research, clinical trials and expert opinion were collated and published as the Surviving Sepsis Campaign guidelines for the management of severe sepsis and septic shock8.

Recommendations were initially graded A to E, with evidence in support of recommendations graded I to V, based on the Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine’s guidelines9. In 2006, the GRADE system10 of recommendations simplified guidance- recommendations were now made at level 1 (‘do it/ don’t do it’) or level 2 (‘you should probably do it/ not do it’).

In February 2008, revised guidelines based on new evidence and current opinion were published11.

The guidelines covered 18 categories:



Initial Resuscitation, including recommendations to support the early recognition of shock through hypotension or elevated lactate, and the application of Early Goal-Directed Therapy12 using fluid resuscitation guided to CVP, vasopressors, blood transfusion and inotropic support where necessary.

Diagnosis, to include the immediate sampling of at least two blood cultures (one drawn percutaneously and one through each vascular access device if in longer than 48 hours) together with other appropriate cultures, and consideration to diagnostic imaging where appropriate.

Antibiotic therapy, with a recommendation to administer broad-spectrum antibiotics within the first hour following recognition of severe sepsis, and to narrow the profile of the antimicrobial agents to target the causative organism(s) as soon as culture and sensitivity results are available.

Source control, through surgery, the removal of potentially infected implants and vascular access devices, or interventional radiology, to be performed as soon as possible following initial resuscitation.

Fluid therapy to be administered using either crystalloids in boluses of 500-1000ml or colloids in boluses of 300-500ml, repeated as necessary based on response.

Vasopressors to be applied in patients with shock refractory to fluid challenges, or during resuscitation to maintain perfusion whilst fluid challenges are being administered, using either norepinephrine or noradrenaline via a central venous catheter, with invasive monitoring of arterial blood pressure as soon as possible. The option of adding vasopressin in persistent shock was given, though it was acknowledged that further trials were necessary to fully recommend this practice.

Inotropic therapy using dobutamine in patients with evidence of low cardiac output despite adequate volume resuscitation and mean arterial pressure, guided to achieve adequate tissue oxygen delivery evidenced by a lack of tissue hypoperfusion.

Steroids at physiological dose (200-300mg hydrocortisone per day or equivalent) to be used in patients with shock persisting despite adequate volume resuscitation and the use of vasopressors, ACTH Stimulation testing was not recommended

Recombinant Activated Protein C administration in patients with high risk of death, for example those with APACHE II score >25, multiple organ failures, septic shock, sepsis-induced Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS).

Blood product administration, including transfusion with packed red cells in the presence of a haemoglobin concentration of <10g/dl (approximating to a haematocrit of 30%), while avoiding the routine use of fresh frozen plasma or other coagulation adjuncts in the absence of clinical evidence of bleeding. Other therapies including erythropoietin and antithrombin were not recommended.

Mechanical ventilation of sepsis-induced Acute Lung Injury (ALI) or ARDS to be performed using reduced tidal volumes and keeping plateau pressures under 30cmH2O. If necessary, hypercapnia is permissible to allow these lung protective strategies. Additionally, a minimum level of Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) was recommended, together with elements of a pre-existing Ventilator Care Bundle including nursing patients in a 450 semi-sitting position and the use of weaning protocols.

Sedation, Analgesia, and Neuromuscular Blockade to include sedation protocols and target sedation levels, together with daily ‘sedation breaks’ designed to reduce overall sedation load and reduce duration of weaning, and the avoidance where possible of neuromuscular blocking agents.

Glucose control in the event of hyperglycaemia, with a recommended target upper limit of 10.0 mmol/l and the use of early nutrition (preferably enteral) to avoid hypoglycaemia.

Renal replacement therapy to be applied in patients with acute renal failure using either continuous haemofiltration or intermittent haemodialysis.

Bicarbonate therapy was not recommended.

Deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis with low dose unfractionated, or low- molecular weight heparin, or in patients with a high risk of bleeding using mechanical prophylaxis such as sequential compression devices.

Stress ulcer prophylaxis using H2 antagonists as first choice, with a possible role for proton pump inhibitors.

Consideration for limitation of support where continued aggressive therapy is becoming inappropriate, but through advance care planning, including the discussion of likely outcomes and realistic goals of treatment with patients and families.
 

Challenges

The Campaign recognised that a 15-page paper, overtly directed at Critical Care clinicians and staff, would have little impact in its raw form outside Critical Care in all but the most motivated and well-resourced institutions. The need to distil these recommendations into the form of change bundles was recognised within this original paper, the output of which will be discussed in detail within the next section of this webpage.

It is widely known that industry funded the $800,000 or so required to collate and produce the initial recommendations, in drawing experts together from around the world and in producing and developing materials. No industry representative was present at or incentivised the guidelines or Bundles, however, and no industry sponsorship at all was sought for the revised guidelines. This initial level of industry funding of a set of international recommendations was new to Critical Care, and drew heavy criticism from some parties. Industry funding continued into Phase III, in which concerted efforts have been made to implement and assess the effect of the guidelines globally. One of the most well-publicised such criticisms was published in the New England Journal of Medicine13. This accused one sponsor of the Campaign of influencing the outcome of the guidelines through the inclusion of one of its products. However, this product was, and remains, the only novel therapy in severe sepsis supported by a large level I trial. The Campaign had distanced itself from direct contact with sponsoring companies during Phase II and excluded such contact with the revised guidelines preparation. Furthermore, a Campaign with such a broad scope and requiring expert opinion from across the globe had not been undertaken before, and almost certainly would not have achieved its current impact in the absence of funding.

Evidence behind certain of the recommendations, and the inclusion of some to the exclusion of others (for example, selective digestive decontamination (SDD), has also been subject to perhaps inevitable debate. One example is the inclusion of a recommendation to achieve tight glycaemic control after initial stabilisation14. This recommendation was based on experience in a surgical population in a closed Critical Care Unit, raising questions as to the validity of this data outside Critical Care and in mixed Units. Following a repeat of the original study in a medical population with negative results15, and the large NICE-Sugar16 and VISEP17 trials also showing negative results, this recommendation was downgraded to Level 2, and the target upper threshold raised to 10mmol/l. Some would question the continuing presence of this and other elements within the Management Bundle- this is discussed in more detail in the next section of these knowledge week pages.


Phase III

Phase III of the Campaign was perhaps the most challenging. By the end of Phase II, a series of guidelines had been produced in the care of the severely septic patient. To achieve these guidelines in their entirety would require the presence of personnel trained in aspects of Critical Care Medicine in the majority of institutions. A key to success would lie in the engagement of staff outside Critical Care in the early identification and immediate management of these patients.

After joining forces with the Institute for Healthcare Improvement, the early products of Phase III were the Surviving Sepsis Campaign Severe Sepsis Care Bundles. This Phase was designed to disseminate the information, form national User Groups, facilitate implementation and examine compliance, improvements and outcomes, Significant progress was made, with data having been collected on compliance with the recommendations and outcome in some 22,500 patients worldwide. At the time of writing this section, a major manuscript detailing the findings of the campaign from submitted data has just been submitted for publication.

The Campaign recommended the use of PDSA cycles to improve compliance with individual elements, and promoted good practice through the dissemination of successful projects and improvement reports.

What is now recognised by national steering groups is that significant challenges remain. A small number of institutions have developed formal links and strategies between Critical Care and Emergency Departments to recognise and manage these patients. Still fewer have attempted implementation outside these two areas.

 

Current sepsis initiatives

The following are examples. Around the world, many organisations have produced individualised guidelines and education programmes in severe sepsis.

International Sepsis Forum

The ISF18 is a charitable organisation formed as a collaboration between industry and healthcare professionals. In 2001, the organisation produced guidelines in severe sepsis management- these were used as a basis for the subsequent SSC guidelines.

The ISF continues to sponsor international educational and academic meetings and original research.


Sepsis Alliance

The Sepsis Alliance19 is a charitable organisation with partnerships with professional bodies dedicated to the early identification and effective management of sepsis worldwide.
 

Pre-hospital sepsis intervention

Attention is being drawn through initiatives such as the Prehospital Sepsis Project in Harvard20 and Survive Sepsis in the U.K.21 to the need for pre-hospital recognition and immediate management of sepsis in view of the time-critical nature of the disease. Near-patient lactate analysis has been proposed as a sensitive marker of the need for aggressive resuscitation in the pre-hospital setting22. Survive Sepsis is working with the Helicopter Emergency Medical Services and the College of Emergency Medicine in the U.K. to develop these principles further.
 

Survive Sepsis

Survive Sepsis23  is an educational resource based in the U.K. It aims to improve early recognition and immediate management outside Critical Care, through multi-professional training of staff from all disciplines. The Resuscitation Bundle is operationalised through the use of the Sepsis Six to facilitate this. Survive Sepsis has links with the Surviving Sepsis Campaign and College of Emergency Medicine, and is working with the National Patient Safety Agency to develop a toolkit for U.K. hospitals.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Emergency Care]]>
document.title: Treatment of severe ankle sprain : a pragmatic randomised controlled trial comparing the clinical effecitveness and cost-effectiveness of three types of mechanical ankle support with tubular bandage. The CAST trial
document.publisher: NIHR Evaluation, Trials and Studies Coordinating Centre (NETSCC)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ EMERGENCY CARE,CLINICAL LIBRARY,TRAUMA (BODY LOCATION),LOWER LIMB,TRAUMA (NATURE OF INJURY),SOFT TISSUE INJURY]]>
document.body:
Conclusion: The below knee cast and the Aircast brace offered cost-effective alternatives to tubular bandage for acute severe ankle sprain, the former having the advantage in terms of overall recovery at 3 months.

Method: A pragmatic randomised controlled trial was designed to reflect a model of practice used in the majority of UK hospital emergency departments. It included an integral evaluation of the cost-effectiveness of the different therapies. A total of 584 participants were recruited and randomised to one of four treatment arms: tubular bandage, below knee cast (10 days), Aircast brace or Bledsoe boot. Follow-up was by postal questionnaire at 4 weeks, 12 weeks and 9 months, with response rates of 83%, 82% and 76% respectively.

Results: The below knee cast offered a small but statistically significant benefit at 4 weeks in terms of pain, foot- and ankle-related quality of life and the physical component of the SF-12. Neither the Aircast brace nor the Bledsoe boot was statistically or clinically better. At 12 weeks the below knee cast was significantly better than tubular bandage in terms of pain, activities of daily living, sports and QoL, and the Aircast brace was better only in terms of ankle-related QoL and mental health. The Bledsoe boot conferred no significant advantage over tubular bandage. By 9 months there were no significant differences. Based on mean direct health-care costs per participant, the Bledsoe boot was the most expensive (£215) and tubular bandage the least (£1.44). Inclusion of indirect costs (sick leave) raised overall costs substantially and removed any significant differences between the therapies. Cost–utility analysis demonstrated that the Aircast brace [£301 per quality-adjusted life-year (QALY)] and below knee cast (£339 per QALY) were more cost-effective than the Bledsoe boot (£2116 per QALY).

Citation: Cooke MW, Marsh JL, Clark M, Nakash R, Jarvis RM, Hutton JL, et al., on behalf of the CAST trial group. Treatment of severe ankle sprain: a pragmatic randomised controlled trial comparing the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of three types of mechanical ankle support with tubular bandage. The CAST trial. Health Technology Assessment 2009;13(13):1–144.

Publication history information: Published February 2009.

Access: Available to the general public.

]]>

111-1UK Resilience

The UK Resilience Website is run as a news and information service for civil protection practitioners by the Civil Contingencies Secretariat at The Cabinet Office.

The website includes the following sections:

  • Latest on UK Resilience
  • Emergency Preparedness - Advice for practitioners on the pre-emergency phase, with generic material on key frameworks (such as the Civil Contingencies Act) and disciplines (such as risk assessment and business continuity).
  • Emergency Response and Recovery - Advice for practitioners on the post-emergency phase, with generic material on key frameworks (such as the UK Central Government Concept of Operations) and disciplines (such as care and treatment of people).
  • Emergencies - Specific assessments and guidance in relation to the broad classes of emergency which their risk framework has identified.
  • The Civil Contingencies Secretariat - background information on CCS
